Type_2: Police said the 71 - year - old was one of three men walking on Kells Avenue at about 08:25 BST . A red car stopped beside the group. A man, described as being in his 30s with dark hair, emerged from the passenger side of the vehicle. He brandished what appeared to be a knife and aggressively demanded that the men hand over their possessions. The 71-year-old, along with the other two men, complied with the demands, fearing for their safety. The assailant quickly snatched a wallet and a mobile phone from the group before re-entering the red car, which then sped off in the direction of the town centre. Police were immediately alerted to the incident. Officers arrived within minutes and cordoned off the area to begin their investigation. Initial inquiries suggest the vehicle was a red Toyota hatchback, though full details are still emerging. Detectives are now reviewing CCTV footage from nearby properties and appealing to anyone who witnessed the incident, or saw a red car acting suspiciously in the area around that time, to contact them. The victims, although shaken, did not sustain any physical injuries.

Type_2:
Lincolnshire Police is taking on about 150 officers over the next two years . The force is restricting applications to people who have lived in the county for at least the past 12 months . The county 's Police and Crime Commissioner , Marc Jones , said the advert had attracted a phenomenal response from high-calibre individuals. He highlighted that the policy of limiting applications to those with a recent connection to Lincolnshire was a deliberate strategy to recruit officers who genuinely understand and are invested in their local communities. "It's crucial that our officers not only reflect the diverse population of Lincolnshire but also possess a deep understanding of its unique challenges and characteristics," Mr Jones explained. "Officers who live here are intrinsically motivated to make Lincolnshire a safer place. They know the streets, the people, and the specific issues that matter most to our residents."

This proactive measure by Lincolnshire Police aims to foster stronger community ties and enhance local policing effectiveness. The residency requirement ensures that new recruits have an established connection to the area, which can lead to greater trust and more effective problem-solving within neighborhoods. While Chief Constable Neil Rhodes retired some years ago, the sentiment of officers being embedded within their communities, as he often advocated, remains a core tenet for Lincolnshire Police. The force believes this local approach will significantly benefit public confidence and visible policing across the entire county. The recruitment drive is a cornerstone of the Police and Crime Plan, designed to deliver a dedicated, locally-rooted police service for Lincolnshire for years to come.

Type_2:
The Arsenal FC midfielder , 24 , uploaded a picture from his 2014 wedding with the caption " un flwyddyn heddiw " , which means " one year [ ago ] today " . In contrast to positive responses , some users expressed confusion while others ridiculed the message . One questioned whether the FA Cup winner was " drunk " The confusion stemmed from a misunderstanding of the Welsh phrase "un flwyddyn heddiw." While perfectly natural and idiomatic Welsh for marking an anniversary  meaning "one year today"  many English-speaking social media users interpreted it literally, failing to grasp its linguistic nuance. Aaron Ramsey, a proud Welshman, had posted the picture from his 2014 wedding on what was clearly his first anniversary in 2015. However, some users assumed the caption meant the picture itself was exactly one year old, which made no sense for a 2014 wedding photo. Others simply couldn't reconcile a 2014 event with a "one year today" caption, leading them to believe the FA Cup winner was confused about his own wedding date.

The decision by Mr. Ramsey to use his native tongue, a common practice for the midfielder, was widely misinterpreted. One Twitter user, @rightjudgeiam, sarcastically tweeted, "Does Aaron Ramsey not know how long a year is? 2014 wedding, posts 'one year today'. Welsh or not, that's just bad maths." This reaction highlighted a lack of understanding regarding the traditional use of such anniversary greetings in Welsh culture. The ridicule often stemmed from assumptions that he was implying the 2014 wedding had only happened "one year today" relative to the 2015 post. This episode underscored the pitfalls of social media, where context, linguistic differences, and cultural nuances are easily lost, turning an innocent, culturally specific message into a subject of online amusement and mockery.

Type_2: Kelly Hewitt , 41 , was found by the side of the A66 on Teesside in March 2014 with severe injuries to her head and body, consistent with being hit by a vehicle. Despite the efforts of paramedics and hospital staff, she tragically died later that day at James Cook University Hospital in Middlesbrough. An extensive police investigation was launched, which ultimately led to the identification of Clare Bailey, the driver of a stolen car, as the person responsible. Bailey, then 26 and also from Middlesbrough, was subsequently convicted of causing death by dangerous driving and jailed, bringing some closure to Kelly's devastated family and the Teesside community.

American Troy Bradley and Russian Leonid Tiukhtyaev landed safely , their Two Eagles Balloon team said . They claim to have beaten the world distance and duration records by flying for more than 137 hours and travelling more than 5,209 miles ( 8,383 km ) . To set the records the team needed to beat the existing records by 1 % . " The Two Eagles balloon team is pleased to report the Two Eagles balloon has landed safely just off the Baja coast near La Paz, Mexico, after an epic journey across the Pacific Ocean. The successful splashdown concluded a historic flight that spanned over five days, shattering previous records for both duration and distance in a gas balloon. The team, led by American Troy Bradley and Russian Leonid Tiukhtyaev, had originally aimed for a landing in North America, possibly as far east as Kansas, but prevailing winds shifted their trajectory southward. Despite not reaching their initial optimal landing zone, the sheer scale of their achievement is undeniable.

The Two Eagles Balloon team confirmed the successful landing via satellite communication and social media updates, stating that both pilots were in good spirits and uninjured. Recovery efforts were immediately initiated by support vessels dispatched to their landing coordinates. This monumental flight, which began on Saturday from Saga, Japan, pushed the boundaries of manned ballooning. Their claimed duration of more than 137 hours surpasses the previous record of 137 hours, 5 minutes, 50 seconds set by the Double Eagle II in 1978. Similarly, the claimed distance of over 5,209 miles far exceeds the existing record for a manned balloon.

For official recognition by the Fdration Aronautique Internationale (FAI), the world's air sports governing body, the Two Eagles team needed to beat the standing records by at least 1%. Based on their preliminary data, they appear to have comfortably achieved this margin for both categories. The flight path of the Eagles took them across vast expanses of the Pacific, demonstrating remarkable resilience and navigational skill from Bradley and Tiukhtyaev. The two aviators endured extreme cold, turbulent weather, and the inherent challenges of prolonged flight at high altitudes within the confines of their gondola.

Their successful completion marks a significant milestone in ballooning history, validating years of planning, preparation, and technological innovation by the Two Eagles Balloon team. While awaiting official certification of their records, the mood among the team and supporters is one of immense elation and pride. This extraordinary journey not only sets new benchmarks but also inspires future generations of adventurers and aerospace engineers. The precision landing off the coast of Baja, though not the specific target, ensured the safety of the crew and the preservation of crucial flight data for record verification. It was a testament to the skill and endurance of American Troy Bradley and Russian Leonid Tiukhtyaev, who have etched their names into the annals of aviation.

Type_2:
RamJam uploaded Southern Rail Tycoon on Thursday , and so far 45,000 people have played the tongue - in - cheek game . The aim is to stop guards from boarding trains , which leads to services being cancelled as profits are collected from passengers . It was inspired by months of cancellations due to an RMT dispute . Once a sufficient number of train guards board on a train and a delayed service eventually departs , the player loses the round, and is presented with a screen showing plummeting profits and irate pixelated commuters storming a virtual London Victoria station. The game, created by Brighton-based indie developer Tom Jackson, under his studio moniker RamJam, has rapidly become a viral sensation. Jackson, a long-time frustrated commuter on the Southern Rail network himself, explained the inspiration behind the satirical hit: 'I spent so many hours delayed on platforms, watching those departure boards mock me, that I just had to channel that frustration into something. It started as a joke among friends, but the more I worked on 'Southern Rail Tycoon', the more I realised how many people could relate to the sheer absurdity of it all.'

The games dark humour resonates deeply with those who have endured the real-life chaos on the network. Players must strategically deploy various humorous obstacles, from broken signal alerts to leaf on the line incidents, all designed to prevent guards from reaching their designated carriages. The more services cancelled, the higher the player's 'tycoon' score, reflecting their fictional mastery over the beleaguered railway. If too many services depart on time, or if guards successfully board multiple trains, the player's 'profit margin' collapses, leading to a swift game over.

Despite its cynical premise, Tom Jackson insists the game is not meant to be a serious political statement, but rather a cathartic outlet. 'Its about making light of a difficult situation,' he stated. 'Its satire. Its a way for people to laugh at the chaos, rather than just fuming about it. Weve had messages from people in London, Brighton, and all along the line saying how much they appreciate being able to turn their anger into amusement, even if its just for a few minutes.' RamJam is now considering updates to Southern Rail Tycoon, including new scenarios and 'disaster' events, as well as a potential mobile version, cementing its status as a cult classic for exasperated commuters everywhere.

What began as a jest among friends evolved into a realization, as I developed 'Southern Rail Tycoon,' that many others could connect with the utter ridiculousness of the situation.'

The game's cynical wit strongly connects with individuals who have firsthand experience of the network's real-world disarray. Players are tasked with strategically deploying an array of comical impediments, such as 'broken signal' notifications and 'leaf on the line' scenarios, all intended to halt guards from reaching their assigned train carriages. Conversely, the game ends abruptly if too many trains depart punctually or if guards manage to board multiple services, causing the player's fictional 'profit margin' to plummet.

Despite its seemingly pessimistic foundation, Tom Jackson emphasizes that the game is intended not as a profound political statement, but instead as a means of catharsis. He articulated, 'Its about finding levity in a challenging predicament. Its a form of satire, offering people an opportunity to jest about the disorder rather than merely seethe over it. Type_2:
Halfpenny 's contract at Toulon ends in summer 2016 , with Cardiff Blues reported to be interested in re - signing the player . The 26 - year - old left the Blues for France in the summer of 2014 . " He 's no different to anyone else . If he is serious about returning we 'd be interested to talk to him , " said Pivac . " We do n't have an endless budget , but I 've said it earlier and nothing has changed . " Pivac 's comments underline the financial realities faced by Welsh regional rugby . While the prospect of welcoming back a player of Halfpenny 's calibre is undoubtedly enticing for the Cardiff Blues , any potential deal would have to fit within the stringent fiscal parameters set by the region . This implies that Halfpenny , who commands one of the highest salaries in European rugby at Toulon , would almost certainly need to accept a significant pay cut to facilitate a move back to the Arms Park . His current deal with the French giants is understood to be in the region of 600,000 to 700,000 per season , a figure far beyond what any Welsh region could realistically afford .

The Wales and British & Irish Lions full-back has been a revelation since joining Toulon , quickly establishing himself as a key figure in their star-studded line-up . His formidable goal-kicking , defensive prowess , and courageous play have made him indispensable for the Top 14 and European champions . However , a serious knee injury sustained during a Rugby World Cup warm-up game in September 2015 has kept him sidelined for the majority of the current season , raising questions about his immediate future and recovery . Despite this setback , his market value remains incredibly high , and Toulon are reportedly keen to retain his services , offering a lucrative new contract . The decision for Halfpenny will likely come down to a choice between the high-octane , financially rewarding world of French club rugby and the potential pull of returning home to Wales , perhaps with an eye on the 2019 World Cup and the desire to be closer to family .

For the Cardiff Blues , a return for Halfpenny would be a massive coup , both on and off the field . He would bring a wealth of experience , a world-class kicking game , and an undeniable attacking threat from full-back . More importantly , his presence would provide a huge boost to the region's profile and commercial appeal , potentially attracting more fans to games and increasing sponsorship opportunities . Pivac has consistently emphasised the need for the Blues to build a squad based on a strong Welsh core , supplemented by key international talent . Halfpenny would perfectly fit this mould , having come through the Blues' academy system before making his name as a senior international .

The challenge for the Blues hierarchy will be to present a compelling case to Halfpenny that transcends purely financial considerations . They would need to highlight the chance to play regular rugby in Wales , to be a central figure in a rebuilding project at the Arms Park , and the opportunity to spend more time within the Welsh national squad environment  something that can be more challenging for players based abroad . While other Welsh regions , particularly the Ospreys , might also express an interest should Halfpenny choose to return to Wales , the Cardiff Blues would likely hold a significant advantage given his historical ties and affinity for the club where he began his professional career . The coming months will be crucial as Halfpenny weighs up his options , and the rugby world watches to see where one of the game's most sought-after players will ply his trade beyond 2016 . The ex - England Under-18 international , who made his Town debut on the final day of the season , is one of 17 players whose deals are set to expire . " It 's a case of waiting to see what happens , " Burton told BBC Shropshire . " There are a lot of lads out of contract and we've obviously got to try and sort that out," Burton told BBC Shropshire, underscoring the considerable challenge facing Town this summer. "It's a huge period for retention and recruitment. Players naturally have their own aspirations, and we understand some will be seeking new challenges or a step up."

Burton admitted the club's financial reality often limits their ability to compete with bigger clubs. "When quality players are available on a free, there's always interest," he explained. "Clubs higher up, like Wolves or Aston Villa, constantly scout for talent. Our role is to convince players that Town offers the right development platform and ambition, not just to match lucrative offers." He stressed the importance of the club's project over purely financial incentives.

Despite the scale, the manager remained cautiously optimistic. "We've had positive discussions with key players we want to retain. It's a two-way street, and we're working hard to secure their futures. For others, it might be time to move on," he added. "We'll also actively bring in new faces to strengthen the squad, ensuring we're more competitive for the Town faithful next season." The coming weeks will be crucial as Burton oversees this significant rebuilding phase, as reported by BBC Shropshire.

Type_2:
Hanjin 's board unanimously agreed to make the court filing at a meeting on Wednesday , a company spokesman said . It faces a cash shortage after failing to persuade key lenders to reschedule debt under a new restructuring plan . Shares of Hanjin remain suspended in Seoul after plunging by as much as 29 % on Tuesday . Hanjin , which is also the world seventh-largest container shipping line, said it has filed for court receivership after its banks withdrew support. The South Korean company's move, following Korea Development Bank's (KDB) decision to halt financial aid, deals a severe blow to global trade, potentially leaving billions of dollars worth of goods stranded. This could become the largest container shipping bankruptcy, disrupting supply chains globally before the peak shopping season. Already, U.S. and Chinese ports refuse Hanjin ships entry, and some vessels have been seized by creditors.

The South Korean government has voiced deep concern, urging domestic rivals like Hyundai Merchant Marine (HMM) to consider taking over some of Hanjin's routes, vessels, and personnel. Financial regulators in Seoul are coordinating efforts to mitigate economic fallout. Hyundai Merchant Marine (HMM), itself recently restructured, has expressed readiness to cooperate with government plans to stabilize the market. This might involve acquiring Hanjins healthy assets, such as port terminals or select ships, to ensure service continuity. Details are pending court proceedings in Seoul.

Creditors, led by KDB, found Hanjin's self-rescue proposals insufficient by the September 4 deadline, leading to negotiation collapse. This signals Hanjin Shipping's likely end, prompting significant reshuffling in global shipping alliances as other major carriers absorb its market share. The incident highlights severe challenges facing the broader shipping sector, long struggling with overcapacity and weak demand. Focus is now on the Seoul court's actions and swift asset transfer to operators like Hyundai Merchant Marine (HMM) to limit widespread disruption.

Type_2: The Very Reverend Martin Thrower , 56 , rector of Hadleigh , Suffolk , held his mobile phone over the top of a toilet cubicle , Norwich Crown Court heard . Thrower was arrested at a shopping centre in Ipswich in August 2016 . He admitted two counts of voyeurism at a previous hearing and his sentence was suspended for 24 months . Thrower was ordered to complete a 60 - day rehabilitation activity requirement, aimed at addressing his offending behaviour and preventing re-offending. As part of his sentence, he was also made the subject of a Sexual Harm Prevention Order (SHPO) for five years. This order imposes strict conditions, including restrictions on his use of internet-enabled devices and a prohibition on entering any public lavatories. Furthermore, Thrower was ordered to pay 2,500 in prosecution costs and a victim surcharge. The court heard details of how the Very Reverend Martin Thrower, who had served as the rector of Hadleigh in Suffolk for 15 years, had committed these offences. His reprehensible actions came to light when he was observed acting suspiciously at a shopping centre in Ipswich, specifically in the men's public toilets, leading to his arrest in August 2016. During the sentencing hearing at Norwich Crown Court, the presiding judge highlighted the profound breach of trust involved in Thrower's conduct, given his prominent and respected role within the Church of England and the local Hadleigh community. While acknowledging Thrower's early admission of guilt and expressions of remorse, the judge unequivocally underscored the seriousness of the voyeurism offences and the distress caused to his victims. The court took into account his previous good character and long service to the church as mitigating factors, which were instrumental in the decision to suspend his prison sentence for 24 months, but firmly emphasized the necessity for both punitive measures and active rehabilitation. This high-profile case sent ripples through the Hadleigh community and the wider diocese of St Edmundsbury and Ipswich, raising questions about accountability and the profound impact of such a conviction on a figure once held in high esteem.

Type_2: Macauley Bonne gave the U 's a 69th - minute lead , but the Spireites , who played more than 70 minutes with 10 men , soon equalised with a penalty . " Teams are vulnerable after they 've scored . Our game management has got to be a lot better , " said Keen , whose side whose side, Colchester United, ultimately succumbed to a frustrating 2-1 defeat against Chesterfield. "It's infuriating to concede almost immediately after you've taken the lead, especially when you have a man advantage for such a significant period of the game," Keen lamented, his frustration palpable. "Macauley Bonne took his goal so well, a really good finish, and that should have been the turning point for us to go on and secure all three points. Instead, we mentally switched off, allowed them back into the game far too easily, and then failed to respond adequately to their eventual winner. The penalty decision itself was debatable, yes, but our reaction to it and the subsequent equaliser was simply non-existent. We talk about showing character and resilience, but today we displayed very little of it when it truly mattered most. We need to be far more professional, more focused, and much more streetwise. The players have to grasp the fact that every single minute of every game counts, especially when you are fighting for every point in a demanding division like this. We allowed ourselves to be severely punished for a clear lack of concentration and game management. This isn't the first time we've let a strong position slip, and it's a worrying pattern that we absolutely, unequivocally must break. It's simply not good enough. We effectively gifted them a point, and ultimately, three. We've got to be more ruthless in seeing games out, both in our attacking play and, crucially, in our defensive discipline. We're creating enough chances, which is a positive, but we're conceding soft goals at the other end. That combination is a recipe for disaster. We need to be tougher, both physically and mentally, to grind out results. This outcome feels like a massive, massive missed opportunity, one that could potentially cost the U's dearly as the season progresses. We simply cannot afford these lapses in concentration if we are to climb the league table and achieve our objectives.
Type_5_1st:

Keen lamented the infuriating experience of conceding so soon after taking the lead, particularly given their numerical advantage for much of the contest, his disappointment clearly evident. Bonne's excellent finish should have been the crucial moment for them to seal victory and claim all three points. Instead, they suffered a lapse in concentration, allowed the opposition back into contention with ease, and then offered an insufficient response to the eventual winning goal.

While acknowledging the penalty decision was debatable, Keen criticized the team's virtually non-existent reaction to it and the subsequent equalizer. He noted that despite discussions about character and resilience, the team showed very little when it was most needed. Keen demanded a much higher degree of professionalism, focus, and tactical astuteness, emphasizing that every minute of every match is vital, especially in such a competitive division. Their clear shortcomings in concentration and game management led to severe consequences.

This wasn't the first instance of them squandering a strong position, a worrying trend that unequivocally needs to be halted, as it's simply unacceptable. They effectively handed Chesterfield a point, and ultimately, the full three. Greater ruthlessness is required to see games through, encompassing both their offensive approach and, critically, their defensive discipline. While they are creating sufficient scoring opportunities, a positive aspect, they are also conceding avoidable goals, a combination that Keen described as a recipe for disaster. They must become tougher, both physically and mentally, to consistently secure positive results.

Keen views this outcome as a hugely squandered opportunity, potentially costing Colchester United dearly as the season advances. Such lapses in concentration are unaffordable if they aim to climb the league standings and achieve their season's objectives.

Type_2: Colin Capp , 23 , of Scotland , attacked Darren Thomas , 45 , while he slept in their cell on Wing B. Consultant forensic psychiatrist Dr Melanie Croy told the jury Mr Capp 's ability to form rational judgement was impaired because of his mental illness . Mr Capp admits killing Mr Thomas but denies murder . Appearing for the prosecution, Mr. John Smith QC, told the jury that while Mr Capp's mental health issues were acknowledged, they did not amount to a defence of diminished responsibility or negate the intent to kill. He argued that the brutal nature of the attack on Mr Thomas, carried out while he was vulnerable and asleep in their shared cell on Wing B, demonstrated a clear intention. Mr Smith highlighted the evidence of pre-meditation, suggesting Mr Capp had planned the assault. Dr Croy, cross-examined by the prosecution, reiterated her assessment that Mr Capp suffered from paranoid schizophrenia, leading to a severely distorted perception of reality. She elaborated on his delusional beliefs, which had intensified in the confined environment of Wing B, particularly in relation to his cellmate, Mr Thomas. She stated that while he understood the physical act of killing, his capacity for moral judgment and rational decision-making was profoundly compromised. Prison officers also described Mr Capp's erratic behaviour in the days leading up to the attack. The defence, led by Ms Sarah Jones, countered that Mr Capp's actions were a direct consequence of his severe mental illness, which had been inadequately managed within the prison system. Ms Jones emphasised Dr Croy's expert opinion, arguing Mr Capp suffered from an abnormality of mental functioning which substantially impaired his ability to understand his conduct, form rational judgment, or exercise self-control. She painted a picture of a young man from Scotland whose untreated condition spiralled out of control, leading to the tragic death of Darren Thomas. The trial continues, with further medical evidence expected before deliberations begin on the complex interplay between mental health and criminal culpability.

Media playback is not supported on this device Kompany was instrumental as City took the lead , pressuring Giorgio Chiellini into turning the ball into his own net . However , he sustained a calf injury as the Italians fought back to win 2 - 1 . " We will have to see how Vincent is on Wednesday , " said City manager Manuel Pellegrini . " We will check and see how serious the injury is . " Kompany , 29 , was replaced by Nicolas Otamendi - City 's 32 million summer signing from Valencia. The Belgium international had been in outstanding form at the start of the season, scoring two goals in four Premier League games and leading a defence that had not conceded a single goal prior to Tuesdays Champions League opener. His forced withdrawal against Juventus is a significant blow for Manuel Pellegrinis side, especially given Kompanys history of calf problems. The City captain has been plagued by similar injuries throughout his career, leading to concerns about his long-term availability.

Pellegrini expressed his immediate worry in the post-match media briefing, acknowledging the severity of losing such a pivotal player. "It's a very important injury for Vincent," he reiterated. "He was playing very well and we hope it's not a serious one. We will know more after he has a scan." The manager also confirmed that Sergio Aguero, who had been substituted in the first half of Saturday's Premier League win over Crystal Palace, was not fit enough to feature against the Italians. The absence of both Kompany and Aguero highlights the squad depth challenges that City might face as they navigate a demanding schedule of domestic and European fixtures. The teams strong start to the Premier League season has built high expectations, and maintaining that momentum will require all players to stay fit and perform.

The defensive partnership between Kompany and Otamendi was one that City fans were eager to see develop, with the Argentine having been eased into the squad. Now, Otamendi is likely to be thrust into a starting role much sooner than anticipated, potentially alongside Eliaquim Mangala or Martin Demichelis. The loss to Juventus, despite Kompany's early influence in pressuring Giorgio Chiellini for the own goal, marked a disappointing start to Citys Champions League campaign. The focus will now shift to how Pellegrini reshapes his defence and inspires a response from his team in the upcoming derby against Manchester United. The media will undoubtedly scrutinize Citys defensive performance in the absence of their influential captain, Vincent Kompany, as they aim to bounce back from this early European setback and continue their impressive domestic form.

Type_2:
West Yorkshire Police confirmed last month that 16,000 tickets issued by police community support officers ( PCSO ) were not valid due because of an " administrative error " . But , the force said there was " no basis in law " for refunds , which would have " come from the public purse " . Many of the drivers paid the fines, unaware of the underlying error. The revelation sparked considerable public outcry and anger among those affected, who felt unfairly penalised by the West Yorkshire Police. Drivers expressed frustration that the force was acknowledging the invalidity of the tickets while simultaneously refusing any form of recompense. Legal experts weighed in, questioning the ethical implications of retaining funds collected unlawfully, even if there was no direct legal precedent for a refund. Some argued that while the law might not explicitly mandate refunds in such a unique administrative error scenario, the principle of unjust enrichment should apply, where one party should not benefit from another's loss caused by their own mistake.

The situation put the West Yorkshire Police under significant pressure to explain why such a fundamental error occurred and why transparency about the issue took so long. Critics pointed out that the public's trust in the police, particularly in the impartiality and correctness of their enforcement actions, could be severely damaged. The Police and Crime Commissioner for West Yorkshire acknowledged the serious nature of the administrative error and stated that a full internal review was underway to understand how the invalid tickets were issued by PCSOs for such an extended period without detection. This review aimed to identify weaknesses in the internal processes and implement robust measures to prevent a recurrence.

For the many individuals who had already paid their tickets, often under the threat of further penalties or points on their license, the news was a bitter pill. Some indicated they would explore avenues for collective legal action, seeking advice on whether a class-action lawsuit could compel the force to refund the monies. Consumer rights groups also got involved, advocating on behalf of the affected drivers and calling for a clearer legal framework to address situations where administrative errors by public bodies lead to financial detriment for citizens. The incident highlighted a significant loophole in the system, where a clear administrative blunder by the West Yorkshire Police left thousands of citizens out of pocket with seemingly no recourse, raising fundamental questions about accountability and citizen protection when dealing with official enforcement. The cost of individual legal challenges for the drivers would likely outweigh the value of the tickets, further complicating their options. The PCSO role and the scope of their powers were also re-examined in light of the incident.

Type_2:
Ahmed Mohamed 's father , Mohamed El - Hassan Mohamed , said he had pulled all his children from schools in the area . According to Mr Mohamed the arrest of the 14 - year - old had a harmful effect . Ahmed 's arrest has been sharply criticised and the charges against him were quickly dropped . Ahmed was arrested at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, after bringing a homemade clock to school that teachers and officials mistook for a bomb. The incident rapidly escalated, drawing national and international attention and igniting a widespread debate about Islamophobia and racial profiling. Ahmed, an aspiring inventor, had merely intended to show off his creation to his engineering teacher. Instead, the clocks circuit board and wires, visible inside a pencil case, led to his apprehension, interrogation without parental presence, fingerprinting, and a trip to a juvenile detention center.

The public outcry was immediate and immense. Prominent figures, including President Barack Obama and Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, offered their support, inviting Ahmed to the White House and Facebook headquarters, respectively. The hashtag #IStandWithAhmed trended globally, highlighting concerns about overreactions and bias in school disciplinary actions.

For Mohamed El-Hassan Mohamed, Ahmed's father, the experience was deeply disturbing. He openly stated his belief that the school's actions were driven by discrimination and Islamophobia, prompting his decision to remove all his children from the local school system. The family later moved to Qatar after Ahmed received a scholarship, though they eventually returned to the United States. The incident became a defining moment in discussions about systemic biases within educational and law enforcement institutions.

Type_2:
Four men deny attempting to smuggle 35 people into Tilbury Docks , Essex . One man died in the container . Basildon Crown Court heard one defendant been caught in France with migrants in the back of his lorry 11 days before the Tilbury incident . Timothy Murphy from Londonderry was fined 5,000 in August . Prosecutor Michael Goodwin told the court that the 35 migrants, including 15 children, were discovered on August 16 last year inside a container on the MV Titania, which had arrived at Tilbury Docks from Zeebrugge, Belgium. Conditions within the sealed container were described as inhumane and life-threatening, with temperatures soaring and oxygen levels depleting rapidly during the 10-hour voyage. The court heard that the victims had been deliberately locked inside the unit.

Mr. Goodwin explained that port officials heard unusual noises coming from within the container. Upon opening it, they found terrified and struggling individuals, many suffering from severe dehydration and hyperthermia. Among them was Meet Singh, 47, from Afghanistan, who tragically died during the journey. A post-mortem examination concluded that his death was caused by a combination of dehydration and hyperthermia.

The prosecution alleges that the four defendants, Stephen McLaughlin, 31; Martin McGlinchey, 49; Christopher Murphy, 20; and Timothy Murphy, 33, all from Londonderry, were part of an organised criminal conspiracy to smuggle people into the UK for financial gain. Mr. Goodwin highlighted Timothy Murphy's previous conviction in France, where he was caught attempting to transport 15 migrants in his lorry. This incident, just days before the Tilbury tragedy, suggested a sophisticated and repeated enterprise.

The court heard evidence that the defendants had been in regular contact via burner phones, coordinating their movements leading up to the incident. CCTV footage and phone data linked them to the vehicle carrying the container and to locations near Zeebrugge. The prosecution argued that the defendants were fully aware of the dangerous conditions the migrants would endure and showed a callous disregard for human life.

All four defendants deny a charge of conspiracy to facilitate illegal entry into the UK and a charge of manslaughter in relation to Mr. Singhs death. The trial at Basildon Crown Court is expected to last several weeks, with further evidence to be presented regarding the planning and execution of the smuggling operation and the role each defendant played. The focus remains on establishing the extent of their knowledge and involvement in this tragic event, which ultimately cost a man his life and put dozens of others in extreme peril at Tilbury Docks in Essex.
Type_5_1st:
Four individuals have pleaded not guilty to charges related to an alleged attempt to illegally bring 35 people into Tilbury Docks in Essex. Tragically, one person lost his life within the sealed container. Basildon Crown Court was informed that one of the accused had previously been apprehended in France with migrants in his vehicle just 11 days before the Tilbury event. Timothy Murphy, from Londonderry, had been fined 5,000 for this earlier offense in August. Prosecutor Michael Goodwin detailed how on August 16 of the previous year, 35 migrants, among them 15 children, were found inside a container aboard the MV Titania, a vessel that had sailed into Tilbury Docks from Zeebrugge, Belgium. The conditions inside the locked container during the 10-hour journey were characterized as "inhumane and life-threatening," with rapidly rising temperatures and plummeting oxygen levels. It was presented in court that the victims had been intentionally confined within the unit.

Mr. Goodwin elaborated that port authorities noticed unusual sounds emanating from the container. Upon opening it, they discovered individuals who were terrified and distressed, many exhibiting severe symptoms of dehydration and hyperthermia. Among those found was Meet Singh, a 47-year-old man from Afghanistan, who sadly perished during the voyage. A subsequent post-mortem examination determined that his death resulted from a combination of dehydration and hyperthermia.

The prosecution asserts that the four defendantsStephen McLaughlin (31), Martin McGlinchey (49), Christopher Murphy (20), and Timothy Murphy (33), all residents of Londonderrywere involved in an organized criminal plot to unlawfully bring individuals into the UK for profit. Mr. Goodwin specifically pointed to Timothy Murphy's prior conviction in France, where he was apprehended trying to transport 15 migrants in his truck. This earlier incident, occurring mere days before the tragic event at Tilbury, indicated a well-organized and recurring scheme.

Evidence presented in court showed that the defendants had maintained consistent communication through unregistered "burner" phones, coordinating their activities in the lead-up to the incident. CCTV footage and mobile phone data connected them to the vehicle transporting the container and to areas close to Zeebrugge. The prosecution contended that the defendants were fully cognizant of the perilous conditions the migrants would face and displayed a blatant disregard for human life.

All four accused individuals have entered pleas of not guilty to both the charge of conspiracy to facilitate unlawful entry into the UK and the charge of manslaughter concerning Mr. Singh's death. The trial at Basildon Crown Court is anticipated to continue for several weeks, with more evidence expected to be introduced detailing the planning and execution of the smuggling operation and each defendant's specific involvement. The central focus remains on determining the full extent of their awareness and participation in this tragic occurrence, which ultimately led to one man's death and subjected dozens of others to extreme danger at Tilbury Docks in Essex.

Type_2:
Chief Inspector of Prisons Peter Clarke published his findings following unannounced inspections . Challenges included staff shortages and increased use of new psychoactive substances , leading to more " unpredictable and violent behaviour " . But inspectors also found good staff - prisoner relationships and a " good range " of training and education . Despite safety declining since 2013 , Mr Clarke described it as a " mixed picture of progress throughout the prison estate. While some institutions demonstrated resilience and effective leadership, Peter Clarke's report highlighted a persistent struggle with systemic issues that continued to undermine the safe and effective operation of many establishments across England and Wales. The surge in violence, often linked directly to the ready availability of illicit drugs like spice, placed immense strain on both resources and the morale of dedicated staff.

A significant challenge identified by Clarke was the ongoing problem of staff retention. This issue, exacerbated by the demanding and often dangerous work environment, meant that many prisons struggled to deliver a full daily regime, leading to extended periods of lock-up for prisoners. Such reduced out-of-cell time often fueled frustration and further escalated tensions within already volatile environments. Crucially, the report by Clarke also drew attention to the critical issue of prison capacity. Many establishments were operating significantly above their certified normal accommodation. This widespread overcrowding, where cells designed for a single inmate were frequently housing two or even three, directly contributed to the documented decline in safety and the notable increase in violent incidents. It severely limited personal space, heightened friction between inmates, and made effective supervision considerably more difficult for staff.

Peter Clarke underscored the urgent need for sustained investment, not just in the physical infrastructure of prisons, but vitally in the recruitment, retention, and well-being of frontline staff. He emphasized that prioritizing the mental and physical health of both prisoners and staff was essential for creating environments truly conducive to rehabilitation, rather than merely containment. The Chief Inspector warned that without tackling these deep-seated structural issues, including the fundamental mismatch between the rising prison population and the available certified normal accommodation, the risk of further deterioration in safety and order within the nation's prisons remained unacceptably high. His findings provided a sobering assessment, urging the government to adopt a comprehensive and strategic approach to adequately resource and manage the future integrity of the entire prison system.
Type_5_1st:
Following a series of unannounced inspections, Chief Inspector of Prisons Peter Clarke released his findings, which presented a nuanced and often challenging picture of the nation's prison system. While some institutions demonstrated notable resilience and effective leadership in difficult circumstances, Clarke's comprehensive report underscored a persistent struggle with systemic issues that continued to undermine the safe and effective operation of many establishments across England and Wales. Among the key challenges identified were significant staff shortages and a concerning increase in the use of new psychoactive substances, both of which contributed directly to more unpredictable and violent behavior among the inmate population. Despite evidence of a decline in safety standards since 2013, the inspections also revealed positive aspects, including strong staff-prisoner relationships and a commendably broad range of training and educational opportunities. Overall, Mr Clarke characterized the situation as a "mixed picture of progress," yet the surge in violence, often directly linked to the ready availability of illicit drugs like 'spice,' undeniably placed immense strain on both existing resources and the morale of the dedicated staff members.

A particularly significant challenge highlighted by Clarke was the ongoing and critical issue of staff retention. This problem, greatly exacerbated by the inherently demanding and often dangerous work environment within prisons, meant that many facilities struggled considerably to deliver a full daily regime. This often resulted in prisoners experiencing extended periods of lock-up, with significantly reduced time outside of their cells. Such limited out-of-cell time invariably fueled frustration and further escalated tensions within environments already inherently volatile. Furthermore, the report critically drew attention to the fundamental problem of prison capacity. A substantial number of establishments were found to be operating significantly above their certified normal accommodation levels. This widespread and severe overcrowding, where cells originally designed for a single inmate were frequently forced to house two, or even three, directly contributed to the documented decline in overall safety and a notable increase in violent incidents. This situation severely limited personal space for inmates, inevitably heightened friction between them, and made effective supervision by staff considerably more difficult and resource-intensive.

Peter Clarke forcefully underscored the urgent need for substantial and sustained investment, not solely in the physical infrastructure and fabric of prisons, but, more critically, in the comprehensive recruitment, ongoing retention, and overall well-being of all frontline staff. He adamantly emphasized that prioritizing the mental and physical health of both prisoners and the dedicated staff was absolutely essential for cultivating environments genuinely conducive to long-term rehabilitation, rather than those merely focused on basic containment. The Chief Inspector issued a clear warning: without decisively tackling these deep-seated structural issues, which fundamentally include the growing mismatch between the continually rising prison population and the available certified normal accommodation, the risk of further profound deterioration in safety and order within the nation's prisons would regrettably remain unacceptably high. His comprehensive findings provided a sobering and stark assessment, which strongly urged the government to adopt a coherent, strategic, and far-reaching approach to adequately resource, manage, and ultimately safeguard the future integrity of the entire prison system.

Type_2: Games will also be held in Bangladesh before the competition returns to India once polling has concluded . The world 's biggest elections start on 12 May and security forces can not be spared from their crucial duties during this period. This forced the initial phase of the Indian Premier League (IPL) to be moved out of the country. The first leg of the tournament, featuring many of the world's top cricketers, was successfully staged in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). This innovative approach ensured that the popular Twenty20 cricket league could continue without disruption, maintaining its high standards of play and global viewership. The decision to split the tournament across multiple international venues  first the UAE, then Bangladesh, and finally back to India  highlights the logistical complexities and flexibility required to manage such a massive sporting event amidst national priorities. The cricket board has prioritised the safety of players and fans, making necessary adjustments to the IPL schedule. While South Africa has hosted parts of the IPL in the past, the current arrangements in the UAE and Bangladesh were deemed most suitable given the timing and logistical considerations. Fans eagerly await the return of the IPL to its home grounds, where the final stages and play-offs are expected to generate immense excitement.

Type_2:
The life - size bronze effigy of the Native American stands in Gravesend , Kent , where she died on her journey home to Virginia in 1617 . Historic England has renewed its Grade II listed status and updated details of her life and role in Transatlantic history , confirming the monument's significance in commemorating Pocahontas, known also as Matoaka. The statue, erected in 1958, serves as a poignant reminder of her brief but impactful time in England, where she was presented to King James I and Queen Anne. Her story embodies the early, complex interactions between European settlers and Native American communities, particularly her marriage to English tobacco planter John Rolfe, which was instrumental in a period of peace for the early Jamestown colony.

The updated Historic England listing now explicitly acknowledges her Algonquian heritage and the often-misrepresented narratives surrounding her life, highlighting the agency she exercised within challenging circumstances. This recognition underscores the effigy's importance not merely as a local landmark in Gravesend, Kent, but as a national symbol of a pivotal moment in global history. The Grade II listing ensures the continued preservation of this unique memorial, reflecting its special architectural and historical interest. It emphasizes her tragic death at a young age in Gravesend before she could return to her native Virginia, underscoring the profound human cost of early colonial expansion and intercultural exchange. The statue, therefore, invites contemplation on themes of cultural encounter, diplomacy, and the lasting legacy of those who bridged vastly different worlds.

Type_2: They lost by seven wickets after being bowled out for just 90 in a rain - shortened match at the Riverside . " We fell a long way short . The game was reduced , but still to be bowled out for 90 in 22 overs is not good enough , " Durham head coach Jon Lewis told BBC Newcastle. "When you're chasing such a low total, you expect your top order to step up and build a foundation, but we just never got going. It was a really poor performance from start to finish, especially considering the conditions were easing. We knew Worcestershire would come hard at us, and they did, but we simply crumbled under the pressure. It's frustrating because we've shown glimpses of what we can do in other games at the Riverside, but this was a significant step backwards." Durham captain Scott Borthwick added, "It's certainly not what we wanted. We prepared well, but the execution wasn't there. Losing early wickets put us on the back foot, and we couldn't recover. Credit to Worcestershire, they bowled exceptionally well and put us under constant pressure. We need to learn from this quickly and ensure we bounce back strongly in our next fixture. We have a lot of talented players in this squad, and we know we're capable of much better. We'll be working hard to address the issues that arose today and come back stronger." Fast bowler Chris Rushworth, a key figure for Durham, echoed the sentiment of disappointment. "It's tough to take," Rushworth commented. "We pride ourselves on our fight, and today we just didn't show enough of it. Dropping catches and misfields at crucial moments didn't help our cause either. We gave away too many easy runs and then failed to make enough ourselves. It's a collective failure, and we all need to look in the mirror." The defeat leaves Durham with much to reflect on as they look to improve their white-ball form.

Type_2: Fewer animals were counted on Scotland 's east coast and in Orkney in surveys by St Andrews University Sea Mammal Research Unit . But the work commissioned by Scottish Natural Heritage ( SNH ) , remains critical for informing conservation efforts, particularly given these concerning findings. The comprehensive surveys undertaken by the St Andrews University Sea Mammal Research Unit provide vital baseline data on marine mammal populations, including seals and cetaceans, in key areas like Orkney and along Scotland's east coast. This long-term monitoring is indispensable for identifying the drivers behind such declines, whether they are linked to climate change, prey availability shifts, or human activities such as increased shipping or offshore development. SNH relies on this detailed scientific evidence to develop robust management plans and advocate for policies that protect these vulnerable species and their habitats across Scotland's marine environment.

Type_2: This Is For My Girls was written by Diane Warren - whose previous credits include I Do n't Want To Miss A Thing and Un - Break My Heart . She described the song - a strident , girl power anthem - as " We Are the World meets Lady Marmalade " . Obama released the single ahead of her keynote speech at the SXSW festival . She will talk about the importance of education for young women and the "Let Girls Learn" initiative, a global effort she has championed to help adolescent girls attend and stay in school. The single, "This Is For My Girls," features an all-star lineup of female artists including Kelly Clarkson, Zendaya, Lea Michele, Janelle Mone, Chloe & Halle, Jadagrace, and notably, Missy Elliott, all lending their voices to support this critical cause. The song aims to inspire and empower girls worldwide, reinforcing the message that their education is vital for their future and the progress of society. Diane Warren's "We Are the World meets Lady Marmalade" vision encapsulates this powerful, collaborative anthem, showcasing unity and diverse female talents for a shared purpose. Obama's appearance at SXSW, a festival renowned for its convergence of interactive media, film, and music, provided the ideal platform to launch this initiative publicly. She plans to emphasize how music and popular culture can be harnessed to drive social change and uplift communities. Her speech will highlight the stories of girls who have overcome immense obstacles to pursue their education, and call on the international community to invest more in girls' education. The collaboration with artists like Missy Elliott not only brings star power but also ensures the message resonates with a broad audience. The single is a powerful auditory representation of the 'Let Girls Learn' campaign's core values: empowerment, education, and opportunity. It underscores the belief that when girls are educated, entire communities thrive, and cycles of poverty are broken. This multi-faceted approach, combining advocacy and cultural outreach through music, exemplifies Obama's commitment to creating a brighter future for girls globally.

Type_2:
World heavyweight champion Fury , 27 , who expressed views on women , abortion and homosexuality , has been asked to attend a meeting in the new year . The BBBofC met to discuss the matter on Wednesday before informing Fury that he must meet with the board . The Briton has denied he is a homophobe and claimed he is " uniting the world " This upcoming meeting with the British Boxing Board of Control is expected to be a crucial one, as the organization seeks to address the widespread condemnation sparked by the boxers controversial remarks. Public outcry intensified following comments where Fury equated homosexuality and abortion with the end of the world, and made disparaging remarks about women.

The firestorm led to significant pressure. Over 140,000 people signed an online petition calling for the Briton to be removed from the BBC Sports Personality of the Year shortlist. Despite the controversy, the BBC maintained Fury would remain on the list, citing that the decision was based on sporting achievement. This stance further fueled debate about the responsibility of public figures.

Furthermore, his comments prompted an investigation by Greater Manchester Police (GMP). The police force confirmed they had received complaints regarding his comments, which were being assessed for potential hate crime implications. While the GMP later clarified no specific crime had been recorded, the police inquiry underscored the seriousness with which his remarks were viewed.

Fury, who secured his world titles after defeating Wladimir Klitschko, has consistently maintained that his comments were taken out of context and that he is not a prejudiced individual, insisting he respects all people. Despite his defence, the ongoing controversy has cast a significant shadow over his boxing achievements and raised uncomfortable questions for the sport. The BBBofC meeting is anticipated to clarify whether Fury will face any disciplinary action, ranging from a reprimand to a fine or even a suspension, depending on the Board's assessment of his conduct and compliance with their code of ethics.

Type_2:
Ashley Broomhall trekked to the summit of 3,560 ft ( 1,085 m ) Snowdon in Snowdonia before tackling Ben Nevis . It took him seven hours to walk up and down the 4,406 ft ( 1,344 m ) Scottish peak near Fort William . On the way up he had a snowball fight with other walkers . He now plans to walk 3,208 ft ( 978 m ) Scafell Pike in the Lake District . Mr Broomhall , from Whitchurch in Shropshire , has been doing the walks to raise money for Cancer Research UK . He was inspired to take on the gruelling challenge after seeing the devastating impact of cancer on close friends and family members. He believes that every step he takes, and every pound he raises, contributes to vital research that could save lives in the future.

His ascent of Snowdon, the highest peak in Wales, provided a challenging start to his mountaineering endeavours, offering stunning views of Snowdonia National Park despite periods of cloud and wind. The subsequent climb of Ben Nevis, the UK's highest mountain, proved to be an even more demanding test of his physical and mental fortitude. He recounted battling the notoriously unpredictable Scottish weather conditions, which ranged from clear spells to biting winds and snow flurries, even in what is considered late spring. The impromptu snowball fight on Ben Nevis's upper slopes offered a brief, memorable moment of camaraderie and fun amidst the arduous trek, highlighting the shared spirit among those conquering the formidable peak near Fort William. The descent, often as challenging as the ascent, required intense concentration and resilience, but the thought of the critical cause kept him focused.

With two of the UK's three highest peaks now conquered, Mr Broomhall is eagerly anticipating his final challenge: Scafell Pike in the Lake District. Completing Scafell Pike will mark the culmination of his personal 'Three Peaks Challenge', an iconic feat that involves climbing the highest mountains in Scotland, England, and Wales within a set period. He understands that while Scafell Pike is the lowest of the three, it presents its own unique difficulties, including rugged terrain and potentially tricky navigation, especially if weather conditions are poor.

Ashley Broomhall has set a fundraising target of 1,500 for Cancer Research UK and has already made significant progress towards that goal, having raised over 900 through a combination of online donations and sponsorship from friends, family, and local businesses. He expressed immense gratitude for the generosity shown by his supporters so far. "The support I've received has been overwhelming," said Mr Broomhall. "Knowing that people are backing me and contributing to such an important cause really motivates me to keep going, even when the climbs get tough. Every single donation helps fund groundbreaking research into new treatments and ultimately, a cure." He hopes that by sharing his journey, he can encourage more people to donate or consider their own fundraising challenges. Donations to Ashley Broomhall's efforts can be made via his dedicated JustGiving page, which can be found by searching for his name or his specific challenge details online. He remains committed to his fundraising mission, aiming to help contribute to a future where cancer no longer devastates lives.

Type_2:
The firm plans to introduce a new fleet of 52 driver - only - operated ( DOO ) trains from 2020 . None of the permanent guards or guard managers would be forced to quit their employment , the company said . RMT union said it was in formal dispute with Merseyrail and its 220 members would be balloted for industrial action, including strikes, over the plans. The union claims removing guards compromises passenger safety and attacks a vital role.

RMT General Secretary Mick Cash said: 'Merseyrails announcement is a kick in the teeth for staff and public. Removing guards undermines safety and accessibility. We won't let Merseyrail put profits over people. Our members are resolute; we'll vigorously campaign to protect the guard's role and ensure safe services. This fight is about safety and security, especially in emergencies. Merseyrail left us no choice but to ballot.'

Merseyrail Managing Director John Tilley responded by stressing safety, stating new DOO trains use advanced technology like driver-monitored CCTV. He said: 'Safety is our priority. All permanent guards and guard managers will be redeployed into new customer service roles on platforms, with no pay loss or compulsory redundancies. This enhances customer service and aligns with modern UK rail practices. We urge RMT to engage constructively, avoiding disruptive industrial action that harms passengers and the local economy.'

The dispute reflects the national controversy over DOO operations, which caused strikes elsewhere. Merseyrail's decision to proceed with its 2020 rollout despite union opposition indicates potential significant disruption across Merseyside.
Type_5_1st:
Merseyrail intends to launch a new fleet of 52 driver-only-operated (DOO) trains starting in 2020. The company reassured that no permanent guards or guard managers would face compulsory job losses. In response, the RMT union announced it was formally disputing Merseyrails intentions and would ballot its 220 members for industrial action, including strikes. The union asserts that removing guards compromises passenger safety and diminishes an essential role.

RMT General Secretary Mick Cash strongly criticized the announcement, deeming it a "severe blow" to both staff and the public. He asserted that the removal of guards jeopardizes both safety and accessibility, adding that the union would oppose Merseyrail prioritizing profits over people. Cash confirmed that RMT members were determined and would vigorously campaign to safeguard the guard's position and ensure secure services, emphasizing this fight was fundamentally about safety and security, particularly during emergencies. He stated that Merseyrail's decision left the union with no alternative but to proceed with a ballot.

Conversely, Merseyrail Managing Director John Tilley highlighted safety as paramount, explaining that the new DOO trains incorporate advanced technology like driver-monitored CCTV. He guaranteed that all current guards and guard managers would be reassigned to new customer-facing platform roles, without pay reduction or forced job cuts. Tilley argued this change would enhance customer service and align with contemporary UK rail industry standards. He urged the RMT to engage collaboratively and avoid disruptive industrial action that would negatively impact passengers and the local economy.

This conflict mirrors a wider national debate regarding DOO operations, which has previously triggered strikes elsewhere. Merseyrail's firm commitment to its 2020 rollout, despite union opposition, suggests the potential for considerable disruption across the Merseyside region.

The union contends that removing guards endangers passenger safety and diminishes a vital role.

RMT General Secretary Mick Cash strongly criticized the announcement, describing it as a "significant blow" to both employees and the general public. He maintained that removing guards compromises both safety standards and accessibility, and pledged the union's resistance to what it sees as Merseyrail valuing profit over people's well-being. Cash asserted that RMT members were determined to actively campaign for the preservation of the guard's role and to guarantee secure operations, emphasizing that this dispute is fundamentally about ensuring safety and security, particularly in emergencies. This monumental clash, which ultimately saw Anderson emerge victorious after a hard-fought battle, firmly cemented its place in the annals of darts, setting a new benchmark for individual and combined scoring in the prestigious event. Type_2:
It was announced on Wednesday that the East Midlands Congenital Heart Centre , at Glenfield Hospital , was to stop children 's surgery services . It was one of 10 units under review nationally with the intention to focus expertise in fewer locations . The charity Heartlink said it would not accept the judgement . A spokesman for the charity , John Rigby , said : " We 're going to take stock , listen to what our reps have said, and then we will plan our next steps. This is absolutely not the end of the fight for the East Midlands Congenital Heart Centre. We believe this decision is flawed and will ultimately harm children and families across the UK. Heartlink will explore every avenue, including legal challenges and further campaigning, to reverse this damaging judgement."

This decision, part of NHS England's 'Safe and Sustainable' review, aims to consolidate specialist services into fewer, larger centres to improve outcomes for children with complex congenital heart conditions. While proponents cite better surgical results and comprehensive care through concentrated expertise, opponents like Heartlink argue that closing established units, especially those with strong reputations, fragments care and increases travel burden for families in regions like the East Midlands.

Glenfield Hospital's children's heart unit is also uniquely known for its Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) service, a vital life support system for failing hearts and lungs. It is one of only four paediatric ECMO centres in the UK. Though the ECMO service wasn't explicitly part of the surgical closure, clinicians and parents worry about the long-term viability of a specialist ECMO unit without a co-located surgical team. This interdependency is a core argument for campaigners like John Rigby, who fear that dismantling the surgical component will inevitably weaken or lead to the loss of the ECMO service, a crucial national resource. The future of specialist paediatric care in the UK is now under intense scrutiny, with questions raised about whether centralisation truly benefits all.

Hina Rabbani Khar 's remarks came hours after the two armies agreed to " de - escalate " tensions after a meeting of their chiefs of operations . Tensions have risen following deadly exchanges along the border last week . The violence has plunged the neighbours into the worst crisis in relations since the Mumbai attacks of 2008 , blamed on militants based in Pakistan . " Instead of issuing belligerent statements by the military and political leaders, it is imperative that both sides show restraint and engage in meaningful dialogue to de-escalate tensions along the Line of Control. The recent violence, following the deadly exchanges last week, has indeed brought the two nuclear-armed neighbours to the precipice of a dangerous confrontation, reminiscent of the heightened animosity seen in the aftermath of the Mumbai attacks of 2008, which India squarely blames on Pakistan-based militants.

Hina Rabbani Khar's remarks, therefore, carry significant weight at this critical juncture. As a former top diplomat, her call for calm and adherence to the agreed-upon de-escalation mechanisms underscores the diplomatic path forward. Ms Khar's emphasis on finding a peaceful resolution, rather than resorting to aggressive rhetoric or military posturing, highlights the need for a sustained effort to build trust and prevent further bloodshed on the border. The focus should now be on ensuring that the understanding reached by the chiefs of operations is implemented in spirit and letter, thereby paving the way for a more stable environment. Both nations must prioritize the well-being of their citizens over jingoistic narratives, working towards a future where such crises do not repeatedly threaten regional peace. The international community, too, has a role to play in encouraging both India and Pakistan to maintain channels of communication and address their core disputes through peaceful means, rather than allowing cross-border incidents to spiral out of control.

Type_2: Cormack , a former chief executive of Aberdeen , sold his software company for 630 m last year . " I can offer both financial support and my time to the club , " Cormack told the Aberdeen website . " I look forward to attracting American investment and strategic partnerships [ to ] help AFC maximise its potential . " Cormack will work with existing board members , including chairman Stewart Milne , while splitting his time between Atlanta and the north east of Scotland . Cormack's move signifies a new era of ambition for the Pittodrie club, long reliant on its loyal local fanbase and shrewd financial management. His vast experience in building and scaling successful tech companies, particularly his ability to identify and leverage growth opportunities, is seen as a major asset that could transform Aberdeen's commercial and global reach. The club has openly sought international investment for some time, with chairman Stewart Milne expressing a consistent desire to expand its network beyond traditional Scottish boundaries. Cormack's American base in Atlanta provides a crucial bridge to the lucrative US market, offering significant potential for new sponsorships, merchandising, and even strategic club partnerships that could benefit both on-field performance and commercial revenues. His stated focus on 'maximising potential' is widely understood to encompass not just player development and consistent on-field success, but also the acceleration of the club's crucial infrastructure projects, including the new state-of-the-art training facilities and the proposed stadium at Kingsford. The synergy between Cormack's modern business acumen and Stewart Milne's deep understanding of Scottish football and local dynamics promises a formidable leadership duo for Aberdeen. Fans across Scotland, and particularly in the north-east, are highly optimistic that this injection of expertise and capital will propel Aberdeen back to consistent European qualification and allow them to more regularly challenge the traditional dominance of the Glasgow giants. The board believes that Cormacks global network and entrepreneurial spirit will be instrumental in securing the club's long-term financial future, moving it towards a more self-sustaining model that combines high sporting ambition with robust financial prudence. His commitment to dedicating significant personal time, alongside his financial support, underscores the seriousness of his intent to help his boyhood club flourish on a truly broader, international stage.

Type_2:
Investigators think the blast was caused by a female suicide bomber from the Islamic State group . Correspondents say Turkey is cracking down on the militants , after previously being accused of ignoring them . But the blast triggered violent protest in Istanbul , with police using water cannon , teargas and rubber bullets . Friday 's bomb hit a group of youth activists planning to cross into Syria to help rebuild the town of Kobane . A video shows the group holding a news conference to discuss their plans , when an explosion rips through the crowd. The chaotic footage, widely circulated online, shows bodies strewn across the ground, thick smoke billowing upwards, and survivors screaming amidst the debris. At least 32 people were killed in the attack in Suruc, a town bordering Syria, and over 100 were wounded. The vast majority of the victims were members of the Federation of Socialist Youth Associations (SGDF), who had gathered at the Amara Culture Centre before their planned journey to Kobane. Their mission was to help reconstruct the Syrian Kurdish town, which had been devastated by a four-month siege by Islamic State militants last year before being liberated by Kurdish forces.

The Turkish authorities swiftly identified the perpetrator as a female suicide bomber with suspected links to the Islamic State group, also known as ISIS or Daesh. This attack marked a significant escalation of the conflict onto Turkish soil, putting immense pressure on President Recep Tayyip Erdogans government. Critics had long accused Ankara of turning a blind eye to, or even tacitly supporting, hardline Islamist groups in Syria as part of its strategy to undermine President Bashar al-Assad. However, following the Suruc bombing, Turkey vowed a more aggressive stance. Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu condemned the 'barbaric' act and pledged to intensify efforts against all terrorist organizations.

The blast immediately ignited widespread outrage and protests across Turkey, especially in Istanbul, where demonstrators clashed violently with police. The previously mentioned use of water cannon, teargas, and rubber bullets underscores the ferocity of these confrontations, as protesters accused the government of complicity or negligence in failing to prevent such an attack. Many felt the bombing was a direct consequence of Turkey's perceived inaction against Islamic State, particularly along its lengthy border with Syria, which has been a conduit for foreign fighters joining militant groups.

In the days that followed, Turkish security forces launched a series of nationwide raids, detaining hundreds of suspected militants from various groups, including alleged members of the Islamic State. The government stated that these operations were a comprehensive crackdown on terrorism, moving beyond just ISIS to target Kurdish separatist groups like the PKK as well. This broader approach, however, drew criticism from those who believed it was an attempt to deflect attention from the core issue of Islamic State infiltration and to suppress Kurdish political movements. The bombing in Suruc profoundly reshaped Turkeys domestic security landscape and its foreign policy towards Syria, signalling a more direct and assertive, albeit complex, engagement in the fight against regional extremism.

Type_2:
An RAF Voyager A330 air - to - air refuelling aircraft will be refitted at a cost of about 10 m. The government says the move will save about 775,000 a year as the plane will be cheaper than chartering flights . The SNP 's Stewart Hosie said there needed to be " absolute transparency " to ensure the " best deal is made on behalf of the tax - payer An RAF Voyager A330 air-to-air refuelling aircraft will be refitted at a cost of about 10m. The government says the move will save about 775,000 a year as the plane will be cheaper than chartering flights. The SNP's Stewart Hosie said there needed to be "absolute transparency" to ensure the "best deal is made on behalf of the tax-payer".

Mr Hosie's demand for "absolute transparency" highlights the need for stringent oversight. He questioned the 10m outlay, despite projected 775,000 annual savings, demanding meticulous scrutiny of long-term value. The refit, involving interior modifications for VIP transport, has drawn criticism. Proponents, however, argue an RAF Voyager A330 offers superior security, flexibility, and availability for ministerial and PM travel over commercial charters.

The government's justification rests on long-term economic benefits and enhanced operational independence. The 10m investment is projected to be recovered via savings in approximately 13 years. Utilizing an existing military asset, rather than chartering private jets, streamlines logistics for sensitive missions. This RAF Voyager A330, primarily a refueller, gains invaluable dual-use capability, maximizing its efficiency within the defence budget.

A Ministry of Defence spokesperson emphasized this project delivers excellent value. The conversion allows the aircraft to maintain core military duties when not needed for VIP transport, preventing the expense of a dedicated executive jet. This multi-role approach is central to an efficient defence estate. Acknowledging the SNP's valid concerns, particularly Stewart Hosie's, the government pledged full disclosure on costs and progress. This aims to dispel "vanity project" perceptions and reaffirm fiscal prudence. Ultimately, the goal is to provide the PM and senior officials with secure, cost-effective travel, seamlessly integrating it with existing military assets. This ensures the RAF Voyager A330 remains a cornerstone for national security and state affairs.

Type_2: Writing in the Sunday Times , the Plaid Cymru leader urged Wales to " speak with one voice " . The UKIP leader and Welsh first minister will lock horns on the contentious issue of Wales's future within the United Kingdom and its relationship with the European Union post-Brexit. Ms Wood's appeal for unity underscores her party's concern that without a coherent and strong Welsh position, the nation's interests could be marginalized during negotiations with the UK Government and Brussels. She stressed the importance of protecting Welsh jobs, industries, and funding streams, advocating for a bespoke deal that reflects Wales's unique economic and social landscape. The UKIP leader, conversely, is expected to champion a swift and complete departure from the EU, arguing that such a move would unlock significant opportunities for Welsh prosperity and autonomy.
