Type_2:
Pte Sean Benton was found dead at the Surrey barracks with five gunshot wounds in June 1995 , while on guard at a perimeter fence . Human rights group Liberty said the Attorney General had given his family consent to apply to the High Court . An earlier inquest recorded a verdict of suicide on the 20 - year - old soldier . The coroner at a second inquest on Pte Cheryl James , who died at Deepcut in 1995, concluded in 2016 that her death was not suicide but an 'unlawful killing', a landmark overturning of the original finding. Pte James was one of four young soldiers who died from gunshot wounds at the Princess Royal Barracks, Deepcut, in Surrey, between 1995 and 2002. The others were Private Geoff Gray, Private James Collinson, and Private Kevin Williams. All four deaths were initially ruled as suicides, leading to years of tenacious campaigning by their families, who consistently maintained that the circumstances surrounding their children's deaths were suspicious and that the original investigations were fundamentally flawed.

The tragic sequence of Deepcut deaths became a national scandal, shining a harsh light on welfare provisions, alleged bullying, and the duty of care within the British Army. Families, often supported by organisations such as Liberty, fought tirelessly to have the original inquest verdicts quashed and new inquiries launched, believing that vital evidence had been overlooked or mishandled. The case of Pte Cheryl James, in particular, gained renewed traction when her parents, Des and Doreen James, secured a fresh inquest following years of arduous legal battles. This second inquest heard compelling evidence of a pervasive culture of fear, harassment, and even alleged sexual exploitation at the barracks, which her family powerfully argued contributed directly to her death.

Similarly, the family of Pte Sean Benton, also found dead at the same Deepcut Barracks in Surrey, has long sought a new inquest into his death. His sister, Tracy Lewis, and other family members have consistently challenged the original suicide verdict, citing numerous inconsistencies in the evidence and a disturbing lack of proper investigation at the time. The recent consent granted by the Attorney General for Pte Benton's family to apply to the High Court for a fresh inquest underscores the profound and ongoing concerns about the integrity of the original inquiries into these tragic deaths.

These landmark cases, driven by the extraordinary persistence and courage of the bereaved families and their dedicated legal teams, have had a profound and lasting impact on the understanding of military deaths and the standards of investigation within the armed forces. They have critically highlighted the urgent need for independent oversight and a transparent justice process when service personnel die in non-combat circumstances. The re-examination of these deeply troubling cases, particularly through the High Court and subsequent new inquests, represents a pivotal moment in the collective quest for truth and accountability, offering a glimmer of hope for long-awaited closure to families who have endured decades of anguish and unanswered questions regarding the deaths of their loved ones at Deepcut and similar military establishments.

Type_2:
James Percival , 66 , said he gave mouth - to - mouth resuscitation to newborn Jonathan Percival in the vicarage in Freckleton , Lancashire , in 2014 . But Ruth Percival , 30 , said she had not seen him make any attempts to revive the baby . The inquest was halted in October when new medical evidence led the coroner to refer the case to prosecutors . In March , the Crown Prosecution Service said there remained " insufficient evidence to pursue a prosecution against anyone in connection with Jonathan's death. This decision meant that the coroner, Dr. James Adeley, could now resume the inquest into the circumstances surrounding the infant's passing. The hearing, which had initially begun in October of the previous year, aimed to establish the medical cause of death for Jonathan Percival, who was just 36 hours old when he died at the vicarage in Freckleton.

During earlier sessions, disturbing details had emerged, including the starkly contrasting accounts from James Percival and Ruth Percival. James Percival, who claimed to have delivered the baby, maintained that he had attempted to resuscitate the infant, performing mouth-to-mouth and chest compressions. He described the baby as being born "blue" and not breathing, prompting his immediate intervention. However, Ruth Percival, the child's mother, presented a vastly different narrative. She testified that she was in the room throughout the critical period and did not observe James Percival making any efforts to revive Jonathan. Her testimony cast serious doubt on his account of the events leading up to the baby's death.

The new medical evidence that prompted the coroner to involve prosecutors was not publicly detailed but was understood to have raised specific questions about the circumstances of Jonathan's death and the care he received. Despite this, the CPS concluded that the evidential threshold for criminal charges could not be met. The family of Jonathan Percival, including Ruth Percival, expressed their ongoing desire for a full understanding of what happened to the newborn. The resumed inquest was expected to hear further expert medical testimony and revisit the conflicting accounts from James Percival and Ruth Percival, with the coroner's ultimate goal being to provide a definitive conclusion on the cause and circumstances of Jonathan's tragic death in Freckleton, Lancashire. The legal proceedings continue to bring to light the complexities and emotional toll of the case for all involved, particularly the parents seeking answers.

Type_2:
The National Environment Research Council defended its decision to hold a public poll to suggest names , in which Boaty McBoatface got the most support . Professor Duncan Wingham said the row had " put a smile " on people 's faces . But MPs asked if he would be made to " walk the plank " by ministers , who The National Environment Research Council defended its decision to hold a public poll to suggest names , in which Boaty McBoatface got the most support . Professor Duncan Wingham said the row had " put a smile " on people 's faces . But MPs asked if he would be made to " walk the plank " by ministers, who were perturbed by the public outcry and ridicule. Despite the clear poll outcome, the National Environment Research Council decided against naming its new 200 million polar research vessel RRS Boaty McBoatface.

Instead, it was named RRS Sir David Attenborough, a choice reflecting its serious scientific mission and vital role in understanding global environmental changes. This sparked widespread public anger and accusations that the NERC had disregarded the democratic will, leading to social media uproar over the perceived hypocrisy.

Prof Wingham, while facing scrutiny, defended the NERC's stance, arguing a more dignified name was essential for a vessel undertaking critical polar and climate research. To appease the public, NERC announced a compromise: a remotely operated underwater vehicle (ROV) on the RRS Sir David Attenborough would be named Boaty McBoatface. This solution allowed the beloved name to be incorporated into the scientific mission, ensuring its quirky legacy endured. The saga became a memorable case study in public engagement, forever linking Prof Wingham and the National Environment Research Council with Boaty McBoatface.

Halfpenny 's Toulon club coach Richard Cockerill was reportedly trying to negotiate the release of the fullback for the Top 14 final on June 4 if the French side reached the showpiece . But Gatland ruled out the prospect and says the schedule is clear . " He will be with us for the entirety of the British & Irish Lions training camp," Gatland stated unequivocally. "The schedule is set, and it's clear. All players are expected to be available from the very beginning." This firm stance highlights Gatland's unwavering commitment to player availability for the crucial tour preparations, which he views as non-negotiable for team cohesion and strategic development. The Lions squad, including key figures like Halfpenny, is due to assemble for their pre-tour camp on May 22, just under two weeks before the proposed Top 14 final. For Gatland, every moment of preparation is invaluable, especially with a demanding schedule of ten matches, including three Tests against the world champions, New Zealand.

The head coach has consistently emphasised that the integrity of the Lions tour takes absolute precedence, and that all selected players must be fully committed and present for the duration of the build-up. This policy has been a clear one from the start of the selection process. The coaching staff believes that any early absences would severely compromise the teams ability to gel and perform at the elite level required to challenge the All Blacks on their home turf. Halfpenny, renowned for his defensive prowess, accurate goal-kicking, and strong counter-attacking game, is considered a vital component of Gatland's plans. His experience from previous Lions tours, particularly the victorious 2013 series in Australia, makes his early integration into the squad even more paramount. Richard Cockerill's attempts to secure Leigh Halfpennys release for such a significant club fixture are understandable from Toulon's perspective. However, Gatland's firm refusal reinforces the unique status and demands of the British & Irish Lions tour, which operates outside the usual club-versus-country dynamics. The focus is now squarely on preparing Leigh and the rest of the squad for the formidable challenge in New Zealand.

Type_2:
Mencap and the Challenging Behaviour Foundation have spoken of the risks of moving patients hundreds of miles . The warning comes as the results of a serious case review into the abuse of patients at the private hospital near Bristol are due to be released . The abuse was uncovered during secret filming by the BBC Panorama programme . Eleven people have admitted charges of ill - treatment and neglect related to the abuse . South Gloucestershire Safeguarding Adults Board ( SAB ) commissioned the review , carried out by an independent investigator. The review meticulously examined the systemic failures allowing horrific abuse at Winterbourne View, the private hospital near Bristol. It delved into circumstances leading to patients being placed far from families and communities, a key concern highlighted by Mencap and the Challenging Behaviour Foundation. Their long-standing campaigns consistently warned against inherent risks of distant placements, which isolate vulnerable individuals, hinder family visits, and create environments where neglect and abuse are less likely to be detected.

The serious case review, commissioned by the SAB, sought to identify not only direct perpetrators but also broader institutional and commissioning failures. It scrutinised oversight mechanisms, or lack thereof, from local authorities and NHS trusts responsible for patient placement at Winterbourne View. Findings are expected to be stark, revealing how a system designed to protect vulnerable adults failed them catastrophically. The BBC Panorama expos, using secret filming to uncover shocking abuse, served as a crucial catalyst, forcing a national reckoning with care quality for people with learning disabilities and challenging behaviour in residential settings.

The eleven individuals who admitted charges related to ill-treatment and neglect represent a tragic failure of individual responsibility, but the review's scope goes far beyond individual culpability. It aims to provide recommendations to prevent such atrocities. These are anticipated to include a significant shift away from large institutional placements towards smaller, community-based care closer to homes and families. Strong calls are likely for improved regulation, robust inspection regimes, and enhanced staff training. Furthermore, the review is expected to highlight the critical need for better communication between care providers, commissioning bodies, and families, ensuring concerns are heard and acted upon promptly.

Mencap and the Challenging Behaviour Foundation have advocated for comprehensive reform, pushing for person-centred care prioritizing individual rights, dignity, and access to a full life within their community. Their warnings about perils of out-of-area placements, often driven by lack of appropriate local provision or cost-saving, have been tragically vindicated by Winterbourne View. The SAB's commitment to releasing the full findings of this independent review demonstrates a crucial step towards transparency and accountability. Lessons from this harrowing episode must drive genuine, lasting change across health and social care sectors, ensuring safeguarding of vulnerable adults remains paramount. The imperative is to learn from systemic failures and implement robust measures to protect those who rely on specialist care, preventing any recurrence of neglect and abuse. The review's findings will undoubtedly inform national policy and practice, reinforcing the urgent need for a fundamental shift in how care is commissioned and delivered for individuals with complex needs, moving from isolated institutional settings towards inclusive, community-based support.

Type_2: The decision was taken despite the 26 - year - old running the Olympic qualifying time on six occasions and coming third in the trials . " I accept I will never win an Olympic medal , " she wrote on eightlane.org . UK Athletics said they do not respond to individual selection decisions, a stance that has often led to frustration among athletes vying for Olympic berths. The 26-year-old athlete in question was Shelayna Oskan-Clarke, whose omission from the initial women's 800m squad for the Games sparked considerable debate within the athletics community. Despite her consistent form and meeting the stringent qualifying standard multiple times, Oskan-Clarke's third-place finish at the national trials did not guarantee her a spot, as UK Athletics' selection policy allows for discretionary picks beyond the top two automatic qualifiers. This controversial approach meant that while Lynsey Sharp, another strong contender, secured her place, the final slot remained a point of contention. Oskan-Clarkes powerful statement on eightlane.org highlighted the immense psychological toll such uncertainty and perceived injustice can take on athletes who dedicate their lives to their sport. Her public lament resonated with many who felt the selection process lacked transparency and fairness, especially given her demonstrated ability to compete at the highest level. The incident underscored ongoing concerns about the subjective nature of some selection criteria, which can leave athletes feeling vulnerable and disempowered, their Olympic dreams hinging on decisions that often seem inexplicable. While UK Athletics maintains its right to select the strongest possible team, the lack of detailed explanations for controversial omissions continues to be a source of tension between the governing body and its athletes.

Type_2: The Met Office issued at yellow " be aware " warning of the conditions at 08:45 for the Highlands and parts of Aberdeenshire and central Scotland . The warning of ice and snow falling to about an inch ( 4 cm ) on ground will persist throughout the day, particularly impacting higher ground and untreated surfaces. The Met Office has advised that these conditions are likely to lead to some difficult driving conditions on many routes across Aberdeenshire, central Scotland, and the Highlands. Motorists are urged to exercise extreme caution, allow extra time for journeys, and consider if their travel is essential. Particular concern has been raised for major arteries such as the A9, A90, and the A82, where strong winds could also lead to drifting snow and reduced visibility, making conditions treacherous. Public transport services, including bus and rail, may also experience delays or cancellations as a result of the challenging weather. Local authorities in Scotland are working to ensure priority routes are gritted, but secondary roads and rural areas are expected to be most affected. The yellow warning is expected to remain in place until at least midnight on Friday, with further updates from the Met Office anticipated as the situation develops. Residents in affected areas are encouraged to check local news and weather forecasts regularly for the latest information and to prepare for potential disruptions to daily routines. Schools in some remote parts of Aberdeenshire have already announced closures or delayed openings. The advice is to dress warmly, carry emergency supplies in vehicles, and avoid unnecessary travel, especially during peak snowfall periods. The combination of falling snow, freezing rain, and high winds creates a significant hazard for drivers and pedestrians alike throughout Scotland, emphasizing the need for vigilance on all routes.

Type_2:
Afghanistan 's intelligence agency blamed Wednesday 's attack on militants allegedly backed by Islamabad . An Afghanistan Cricket Board ( ACB ) statement it could not agree to play against " a country where terrorists are housed and provided safe havens " . The Pakistan Cricket Board ( PCB ) later accused the ACB of " playing politics " . Pakistan has rejected an Afghan claim that it was involved the attack The unprecedented decision by the Afghanistan Cricket Board (ACB) to halt cricketing ties underscores escalating diplomatic tensions between Kabul and Islamabad. This dramatic move threatens to derail a planned T20 series and future bilateral engagements, as the ACB declared it could not play against "a country where terrorists are housed and provided safe havens." The Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) quickly hit back, accusing the ACB of "playing politics" and lamenting the politicization of sports. "Cricket should unite people, not divide them," a PCB official reportedly stated, emphasizing the sport's traditional spirit.

The PCB further highlighted its historical role in nurturing Afghan talent, with many Afghan cricketers gaining crucial experience through Pakistan's domestic leagues and the Pakistan Super League (PSL). This cricketing bridge, built over years of shared passion, now appears severely damaged. From Afghanistan's perspective, however, the direct link established by its intelligence agencies between the recent attack and elements allegedly operating from Pakistani soil makes normal sporting exchanges untenable. The ACBs statement reflects a broader national sentiment demanding accountability and an end to what Kabul views as cross-border terrorism. The Afghan government has consistently accused Islamabad of supporting militant groups that destabilize Afghanistan, a charge Pakistan vehemently denies, asserting its own struggles with terrorism originating from across the border.

The impasse poses a significant challenge for the future of cricket between the two nations. The diplomatic fallout from the attack is thus casting a long shadow over any prospects of immediate reconciliation, not just in politics but also on the cricket field. The Afghanistan Cricket Boards defiant stance, backed by the Afghan government, signals that until Afghanistan perceives a tangible shift in Islamabad's policy regarding alleged militant safe havens, the sporting arena will remain inextricably linked to their deeply entrenched political grievances. The Pakistan Cricket Board continues to advocate for the separation of sports and politics, but without a resolution to the underlying security concerns, the future of cricket between these passionate rivals remains highly uncertain.

Type_2: The 31 - year - old Australian was hurt during the Chiefs ' narrow Champions Cup loss at Ulster and needs surgery . Salvi joined the Chiefs in the summer of 2015 from Leicester and became a key part of the side that made last season 's Premiership final . His absence is a significant blow for Rob Baxter's side, particularly as they navigate a challenging period in both the Premiership and Champions Cup. Salvi, known for his relentless work rate and breakdown prowess, has been a consistent performer, quickly establishing himself as a fan favourite since his arrival from Leicester. His ability to disrupt opposition play and secure crucial turnovers has been vital to the Chiefs' dynamic style of rugby. Coach Rob Baxter expressed his disappointment at the injury, acknowledging Salvi's immense contribution. "Matt is a hugely respected member of our squad, both on and off the field," Baxter commented. "His commitment and energy are infectious, and he's played a massive role in our success over the past couple of seasons. It's a tough blow for him personally, and for us as a team, especially coming off the back of such a hard-fought Champions Cup encounter against Ulster." The recovery period for such surgery is expected to rule the Wallaby back-rower out for several months, severely impacting his involvement in the remainder of the current campaign. This setback will test the depth of the Chiefs' formidable squad as they continue their push for silverware, hoping to replicate or even surpass last season's achievements. Salvi's journey from Australia, through a successful spell at Leicester, to becoming a lynchpin at Sandy Park highlights his resilience and dedication, qualities he will undoubtedly draw upon during his rehabilitation.

SSI took over the former Tata Steel complex after it was mothballed in 2010 and employs almost 2,000 people . Ms Soubry said EU rules meant state cash could not be directly used to support British steel production . SSI UK Business Director Cornelius Louwrens said the move was 'extremely disappointing' but 'absolutely essential' given the challenging market conditions. He emphasized that the decision was taken to preserve the long-term viability of the business, exploring all options for its future. The Redcar plant, a symbol of industrial heritage in the North East, now faces an uncertain future, sparking fears for the jobs of its almost 2,000 workers and the wider supply chain. Trade unions called for urgent government intervention, arguing that the closure would be a devastating blow to the region and the UK's manufacturing capacity. Despite Ms Soubry's comments on EU restrictions, pressure is mounting on ministers to find a solution that could save the iconic steelworks. The company had previously warned about the impact of cheap imports and high energy costs, issues that have plagued the UK steel industry for years. The blast furnace, one of the largest in Europe, is a critical component of the integrated steelworks, and its shutdown effectively halts primary steelmaking on the site. The community, still recovering from previous closures under Tata Steel, watches anxiously as the fate of Redcar hangs in the balance, underscoring the broader challenges facing heavy industry in the UK.

Type_2: Queen 's Lodge , Colwyn Bay , was the home of the first Lord Colwyn . It became two care homes following the death of Frederick Henry Smith , an industrialist and banker , in 1946 These care homes, still known to many locally as 'the lodge', continued to operate for several decades. They were later overseen by the Merseyside Hospitals Council, reflecting the significant post-war changes in healthcare provision across Wales. The substantial property eventually ceased its function as care homes, with its future use subject to various proposals over the years. Its historical and architectural significance, including its transformation from a grand private residence into multiple care facilities after Frederick Henry Smith's death, is comprehensively documented by the National Monuments Record of Wales. This record preserves the detailed history of the lodge and its evolving role within the community of Colwyn Bay, Wales.

Type_2: Campaign group Liberty says the powers , which are used by intelligence agencies to collect large volumes of data from electronic devices , amount to an " assault on our freedom " . The Investigatory Powers Act gained royal assent in November . The government has said it will defend the act . Powers covered by the act allow state agencies to control and alter electronic devices , read texts , online messages and emails, monitor phone calls and access location data. This controversial legislation, dubbed the 'Snooper's Charter' by critics, grants extensive surveillance capabilities to agencies like MI5, MI6, and GCHQ. Liberty, with director Martha Spurrier at the forefront, argues the act constitutes an "assault on our freedom" by enabling mass surveillance. Spurrier contends it permits indiscriminate data collection on ordinary citizens, setting a dangerous precedent for civil liberties rather than targeting specific threats. She calls it one of the most extreme surveillance laws in a democracy. Despite significant opposition, including from the House of Lords which sought stronger privacy protections, the Investigatory Powers Act gained royal assent. The government, under then-Prime Minister Theresa May, defended the act as vital for national security in the digital age. May argued it merely updated existing powers, bringing transparency and proper oversight through independent judicial commissioners. However, Liberty and other privacy advocates continue to challenge its proportionality. They highlight concerns over bulk data collection, device hacking, and the requirement for internet service providers to retain browsing history for 12 months, viewing these as unacceptable intrusions. Legal challenges are anticipated, potentially reaching the European Court of Human Rights. The act underscores a fundamental tension between state security and individual freedoms, with critics warning of a chilling effect on free expression.
Type_5_1st:
Campaign group Liberty strongly opposes the Investigatory Powers Act, labelling its provisions an "assault on our freedom" due to their enabling of mass surveillance. This law, enacted in November and nicknamed the 'Snooper's Charter' by critics, empowers agencies like MI5, MI6, and GCHQ with broad surveillance capabilities. Liberty's director, Martha Spurrier, argues the act allows for indiscriminate data gathering on ordinary citizens, creating a perilous precedent for civil liberties rather than focusing on genuine threats. She considers it among the most extreme surveillance legislation in democratic nations.

The Act's powers include collecting vast amounts of data from electronic devices, remotely controlling or modifying them, intercepting communications such as texts, online messages, and emails, monitoring phone calls, and tracking location. It also mandates internet service providers to store users' browsing histories for a year. Despite considerable opposition, including calls from the House of Lords for enhanced privacy safeguards, the government, led by then-Prime Minister Theresa May, successfully passed the bill. May maintained the Act was essential for national security in the digital age, asserting it merely updated existing powers while introducing transparency and oversight via independent judicial commissioners.

However, Liberty and other privacy advocates continue to dispute its proportionality, citing concerns over bulk data collection, device hacking, and the year-long browsing history retention mandates as unacceptable intrusions. Anticipated legal challenges, potentially reaching the European Court of Human Rights, highlight the inherent conflict between state security and individual rights, with critics warning of a chilling effect on free expression.
Type_5_3rd:
The civil liberties organization, Liberty, has been a prominent detractor of the Investigatory Powers Act, lambasting its provisions as an "assault on our freedom" because they enable widespread governmental surveillance. This legislation, enacted in November and disparagingly known as the 'Snooper's Charter' by its opponents, grants extensive monitoring capabilities to security agencies like MI5, MI6, and GCHQ. According to Martha Spurrier, Liberty's director, the Act facilitates the indiscriminate collection of personal data from ordinary citizens, establishing a perilous precedent for civil liberties rather than precisely targeting genuine threats. She considers this among the most extreme surveillance laws implemented in democratic nations.

The powers sanctioned by the Act encompass gathering vast amounts of information from digital devices, the ability to remotely control or alter them, intercepting electronic communications such as texts, online messages, and emails, monitoring phone conversations, and tracking individuals' physical whereabouts. Furthermore, it mandates that internet service providers store users' web browsing histories for a full year. Despite significant opposition, including calls from the House of Lords for enhanced privacy safeguards, the government, then under Prime Prime Minister Theresa May, successfully enacted the bill. May contended that the Act was vital for national security in the digital age, asserting it merely updated existing authority while improving accountability and transparency through independent judicial oversight.

Nonetheless, Liberty, along with other privacy advocates, continues to question the Act's proportionality. They highlight concerns regarding mass data collection, unauthorized access to devices, and the compulsory year-long retention of browsing histories as unacceptable encroachments on personal privacy. Upcoming legal challenges, potentially escalating to the European Court of Human Rights, underscore the fundamental tension between the state's security imperatives and individual freedoms, with critics warning of a chilling effect on free expression.

Type_2:
Thomas Groome , 53 , was last seen by his family in Thorne in Doncaster on New Year 's Day , 2010 . Jason Thaxter , of Hexthorpe , Doncaster , was convicted of murder and conspiracy to prevent a burial following a five - week trial . He was jailed at Sheffield Crown Court and ordered to serve a minimum of 17 years in prison before being considered for parole. Thomas Groome's disappearance on New Year's Day, 2010, from Thorne, Doncaster, sparked a major three-year investigation by South Yorkshire Police. Despite extensive searches, Mr Groome's body has never been found, a distressing fact that remained central throughout the entire legal process.

The five-week trial at Sheffield Crown Court heard how Jason Thaxter, from Hexthorpe, Doncaster, had brutally murdered Mr Groome and then taken deliberate steps to conceal his body, leading to the charge of conspiracy to prevent a burial. This absence of remains presented significant challenges for detectives, yet the prosecution successfully built a compelling case against Thaxter.

In sentencing, Judge Roger Thomas QC described Thaxter's actions as "callous and calculated," highlighting the immense and prolonged anguish caused to Mr Groome's family, who have been denied the opportunity to lay him to rest. South Yorkshire Police commended their team's perseverance in securing a conviction in this complex "no-body" murder case. Mr Groome's family continue to make heartfelt appeals for information regarding the location of his remains, hoping to finally bring him home and find some peace.

Type_2:
Profits at the technology giant were up 17 % from the same period last year . " Our devices and services transformation is progressing , " said boss Steve Ballmer in a statement . He added that Microsoft is launching a " wide range " of new products in the coming quarter . The report shed no light on who is to replace Mr Ballmer , who announced plans to retire within the next year Profits at the technology giant were up 17 % from the same period last year . Our devices and services transformation is progressing , " said boss Steve Ballmer in a statement . He added that Microsoft is launching a " wide range " of new products in the coming quarter . The report shed no light on who is to replace Mr Ballmer , who announced plans to retire within the next year. The lack of clarity regarding Mr Ballmer's successor cast a shadow over an otherwise positive earnings report. Investors and analysts alike are keenly watching the search for the next chief executive, a decision that will profoundly shape Microsoft's future direction. Speculation has been rife, with names from both inside and outside the company being floated, including former Skype president Tony Bates and Ford CEO Alan Mulally, though Microsoft has remained tight-lipped about the process. The transition comes at a pivotal time for the Redmond-based software giant as it strives to redefine itself beyond its traditional Windows and Office strongholds.

This "devices and services" push, championed by Steve Ballmer, represents a fundamental shift for Microsoft. It aims to integrate hardware and software more seamlessly, mirroring the successful strategies of competitors like Apple. However, the pivot has not been without its challenges. The reception to Windows 8, Microsoft's flagship operating system designed for touch-enabled devices, has been mixed since its launch, failing to significantly boost PC sales in a declining market. The acquisition of Nokia's devices and services division, a deal spearheaded by Mr Ballmer, is central to this strategy, promising Microsoft greater control over its smartphone ecosystem and a stronger competitive position in the mobile space. Analysts believe that the success of this transformation will largely depend on the new leadership's ability to execute on Ballmer's vision while also adapting to rapidly evolving consumer demands.

The promised "wide range" of new products likely includes further iterations of the Surface tablet, potentially a smaller version, and new smartphones under the Nokia brand. The next generation Xbox console, though already launched, will also continue to be a key revenue driver. Despite the positive earnings, some analysts remain cautious, highlighting the intense competition in both the enterprise and consumer markets. The departing Mr Ballmer leaves behind a company in the midst of a massive strategic overhaul, and the next CEO will face the immense task of accelerating this transformation while simultaneously rekindling investor confidence and innovating at a pace previously unseen at Microsoft. The coming quarters will be critical in determining whether Microsoft can truly shed its legacy image and emerge as a dominant force in the mobile-first, cloud-first world.

However, the report offered no details concerning Mr. Ballmer's replacement, who had earlier declared his intention to retire within the coming year. Type_2: The talks come after Papua New Guinea 's Supreme Court ruled the facility unconstitutional , overturning a deal reached between the governments . Australia sends asylum seekers there under its offshore processing policy . Papua New Guinea has now said it will close the facility , but it is not clear when that could happen . Manus Island was first opened in 2001 , and along with Australia 's other offshore processing centres , has played a central role in Australia 's controversial asylum policy . Papua New Guinea 's high commissioner to Australia, Charles Lepani, has indicated that the closure of the Manus Island detention centre will be a gradual process, emphasizing collaboration with Australia for the humane resettlement of the asylum seekers currently housed there. The Supreme Court ruling has put both nations in a challenging position, requiring careful diplomacy to resolve complex human rights and political issues. Lepani stressed that while Papua New Guinea respects the court's decision, the welfare of the detainees remains paramount. He stated the exact timeline for closure is still being determined, but it will not be immediate. This necessitates ongoing discussions between Australia and Papua New Guinea to develop a comprehensive plan for the future of the hundreds of men who have been in limbo for years. The long-standing agreement between the two countries, which saw Australia sending asylum seekers to Manus as part of its 'Pacific Solution' policy, has been a contentious issue internationally, drawing criticism from human rights organizations. The Supreme Court's ruling, which found that the detention of asylum seekers on Manus Island violated their constitutional right to personal liberty, has now forced both governments to confront the moral and legal implications of the policy. The court's decision was a landmark moment, highlighting the inherent tensions between national security policies and fundamental human rights. The Australian government, under Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, has acknowledged the ruling and stated its commitment to working with Papua New Guinea to manage the transition. However, Australia maintains its policy that none of the asylum seekers sent to Manus will ever be resettled in Australia. This stance further complicates the situation, as viable third-country resettlement options are limited. Charles Lepani has called for international cooperation and support to find sustainable solutions, suggesting the international community has a role to play in addressing this humanitarian crisis. The future of the Manus facility, and Australia's entire offshore processing system, remains uncertain, with significant pressure mounting on both governments to provide clarity and compassionate solutions for those affected. The ruling underscores the importance of judicial independence in upholding human rights, even in the face of complex bilateral agreements. The protracted nature of the issue and the lack of immediate clear solutions mean that the closure will be a carefully managed, multi-stage process, involving extensive diplomatic efforts and logistical planning. Papua New Guinea is committed to upholding its legal obligations while also seeking to maintain strong bilateral ties with Australia. The international community continues to monitor the situation closely, awaiting concrete steps towards the resolution of this prolonged humanitarian challenge. The welfare of the detainees and their eventual resettlement is the primary focus for all parties involved.
Type_5_1st:
The recent, significant ruling by Papua New Guinea's Supreme Court, which authoritatively declared the Manus Island detention facility unconstitutional and thereby completely invalidated a prior, long-standing inter-governmental agreement, has now directly triggered a series of urgent discussions and diplomatic engagements. For many years, this specific site has served as a cornerstone of Australia's controversial offshore processing policy, where asylum seekers are sent for their claims to be assessed outside Australian territory. Following this pivotal legal decision, Papua New Guinea has formally announced its clear intention to proceed with the closure of the center, though the precise timeline for this significant action, along with its logistical details, is still actively being determined.

Initially opened in 2001, Manus Island, much like Australia's other remote offshore processing centres, has consistently held a profoundly significant, and frequently contentious, position in the overall framework of Australia's asylum policy. Charles Lepani, Papua New Guinea's high commissioner to Australia, has clearly articulated that the impending closure of the Manus Island detention centre will undeniably be a protracted and carefully phased process, rather than an abrupt shutdown. He further stressed the paramount importance of close collaboration and joint efforts with Australia, aiming to ensure the humane and dignified resettlement of all asylum seekers who are presently housed at the facility. This far-reaching judicial decision has consequently placed both sovereign nations in an exceptionally challenging and delicate position, urgently demanding meticulous diplomacy and strategic negotiation to navigate the intricate web of complex human rights and pressing political issues involved. Lepani unequivocally reaffirmed Papua New Guinea's profound respect for the Supreme Court's verdict, but concurrently emphasized that the welfare, safety, and human dignity of the detainees would remain the absolute paramount consideration throughout the process. While a precise and definitive timeline for the facility's complete cessation of operations is still pending further determination, he explicitly confirmed that the closure would certainly not be immediate, requiring careful planning.

Continuous and productive discussions between Australia and Papua New Guinea are, therefore, absolutely essential to meticulously develop and implement a truly comprehensive and sustainable plan for the long-term future of the hundreds of vulnerable men who have, regrettably, remained in a state of indefinite limbo for numerous years. This long-standing and often controversial agreement, under which Australia systematically dispatched asylum seekers to Manus as a cornerstone of its contentious 'Pacific Solution' policy, has consistently been a source of global contention and has drawn widespread, severe criticism from numerous prominent human rights organizations worldwide. The Supreme Court's unequivocal finding, which unequivocally established that the indefinite detention of asylum seekers on Manus Island fundamentally violated their constitutional right to personal liberty, now definitively compels both governments to directly confront the profound moral, ethical, and legal ramifications stemming from this highly scrutinized policy. This landmark and historically significant court decision powerfully underscored the deep-seated and inherent tensions that frequently arise between national security policies aimed at border protection and the unwavering commitment to upholding fundamental human rights.

The Australian government, under the leadership of Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, promptly acknowledged the court's pivotal ruling and publicly pledged its unwavering commitment to closely collaborate with Papua New Guinea in effectively managing the complex transition process. However, Australia steadfastly and unequivocally maintains its stringent policy position that absolutely no asylum seekers who were transferred to Manus Island will ever be granted resettlement within Australia itself. This unwavering and uncompromising stance severely complicates the already difficult situation, as the availability of viable and long-term resettlement options in other third countries remains notably limited, creating a significant humanitarian dilemma. Charles Lepani has proactively appealed for broader international cooperation and robust support from global partners to urgently identify truly sustainable and humane solutions, explicitly suggesting that the wider international community bears a shared responsibility in adequately addressing what he has unequivocally described as a pressing humanitarian crisis.

Consequently, the definitive future of the Manus facility, and indeed the broader viability of Australia's entire offshore processing system, remains deeply uncertain and subject to ongoing political and legal developments. Significant and increasing pressure is mounting on both the Australian and Papua New Guinean governments to urgently provide much-needed clarity and compassionate, long-term resolutions for all the individuals whose lives have been profoundly affected by this situation. This pivotal ruling powerfully highlights the critical and enduring importance of judicial independence and its role in fearlessly upholding fundamental human rights, even when such decisions challenge existing, intricate bilateral agreements between sovereign nations. Given the protracted and complex nature of this enduring issue, coupled with the current absence of any immediate, clear, or simple solutions, the actual closure of the facility is anticipated to be a meticulously and carefully managed, multi-stage process. This will inherently involve extensive diplomatic efforts, intricate logistical planning, and significant cross-governmental coordination. Papua New Guinea remains steadfastly committed to fully upholding its legal and constitutional obligations derived from the court's ruling, while simultaneously striving to preserve and strengthen its historically strong bilateral ties and relationship with Australia. The international community continues to monitor the evolving situation closely and with keen interest, keenly awaiting concrete and decisive steps towards the effective resolution of this prolonged and deeply concerning humanitarian dilemma. Ultimately, the immediate welfare, safety, and the dignified, eventual resettlement of all the detainees remain the unequivocal primary focus and guiding principle for all parties and stakeholders involved in this complex matter.

Type_2:
The fine print of the deal suggests something slightly different , and shows that GM has in fact taken a hit of up to 6bn in order to get shot of Vauxhall and Opel . First , a big chunk of the price - three - quarters of a billion pounds - is not for car plants , but for loans taken out by the owners of Opel and Vauxhall This unusual arrangement highlights that rather than simply selling an asset, GM is effectively paying to divest itself of a long-standing financial burden. The bulk of the 6bn charge, however, stems from the substantial pension liabilities that GM has chosen to retain rather than offload to Peugeot. Estimates place GM's retention of pension obligations for Vauxhall and Opel employees at well over 5bn, reflecting the enormous cost of legacy commitments built up over decades. This decision, made in Detroit, underscores GM's strategic imperative to clear its balance sheet of European losses that have plagued its financial performance for years. By retaining these liabilities, GM avoids the potentially complex and protracted negotiations that would have been required to transfer them to Peugeot, thereby expediting the sale and providing a clean break.

The deal, therefore, is less about GM selling a profitable division and more about a costly exit from a market where it has struggled to compete consistently. For Peugeot, this acquisition of Vauxhall and Opel presents an opportunity to significantly increase its market share in Europe and achieve substantial economies of scale. However, it also means inheriting a business that has been unprofitable for nearly two decades, requiring significant restructuring and investment to turn around. The challenge for Peugeot will be to integrate the Vauxhall and Opel operations efficiently, streamline production, and reduce costs without alienating the workforce or diluting the brands' appeal. The focus for Vauxhall under its new ownership will be on platform sharing with Peugeot models, standardizing components, and rationalizing the product portfolio to improve profitability. This move signals a definitive shift in GM's global strategy, allowing it to concentrate resources on more lucrative markets like North America and China, and invest heavily in future technologies such as electric and autonomous vehicles. The severance of ties with Vauxhall and Opel frees up capital and management attention, enabling GM to pursue its growth ambitions elsewhere, even if the price of freedom came with a hefty 6bn cheque.

Ellis pleaded guilty to manslaughter at Swansea Crown Court, with the judge adjourning the case for sentencing. The court heard that Mr Warburton's death followed an altercation.

Type_2: Mr Mills had been deputy chairman of the group designated the lead " out " campaign by the Electoral Commission . He has previously claimed the campaign was torn by internal feuding . He was reported to have been on the verge of quitting in February when Labour MP Kate Hoey joined a rival out campaign . In his resignation letter , the home shopping magnate said he had " come to believe that it would be useful and more effective for the broader 'Leave' campaign, and indeed the national interest, if I were to step aside from my current role. My decision is not taken lightly and stems from a growing conviction that the internal dynamics within our designated lead campaign, as sanctioned by the Electoral Commission, have unfortunately reached a point where they risk undermining our collective efforts. Despite tireless work and dedication from many individuals, the persistent internal feuding and divergent strategic approaches have, regrettably, become an increasingly debilitating distraction. These divisions, which I have previously highlighted, prevent the unified and forceful message that is absolutely essential if we are to convince the British public that a future outside the European Union is not only viable but preferable. The emergence of multiple, often competing, 'out' campaigns, exemplified by the participation of figures such as Labour MP Kate Hoey in an alternative platform, further fragments our message and dilutes the impact of the arguments for departure from the EU. While diversity of opinion is a hallmark of a healthy democracy, the current landscape within the 'Leave' movement risks confusing voters and playing into the hands of those who wish to remain. For the 'Leave' campaign to succeed, it requires absolute clarity of purpose, a laser-like focus on the core arguments for sovereignty and economic opportunity, and above all, a cohesive and disciplined leadership that speaks with one voice. It needs to be perceived by the public as a unified force, not a collection of warring factions. It is my earnest hope that by removing myself from the immediate leadership structure, it may create an opportunity for a renewed focus on unity and strategic coherence. My commitment to seeing Britain leave the European Union remains absolute, and I will continue to support the broader 'Leave' cause from outside this specific leadership role. I wish the campaign every success in the vital months ahead. The stakes for our nation are incredibly high, and it is imperative that the 'Leave' side presents an irrefutable case for a brighter, independent future for the United Kingdom.

In his letter of resignation, the home shopping entrepreneur conveyed his belief that his stepping aside from his present role would prove more advantageous and effective for the broader 'Leave' campaign, as well as for the national interest. Such divisions, which he had previously underscored, were actively preventing the formation of the unified and forceful message deemed absolutely essential to persuade the British public that a future outside the European Union is not only viable but demonstrably preferable.

The proliferation of multiple, often competing, 'out' campaignsillustrated by the involvement of figures like Labour MP Kate Hoey in an alternative platformserved to further fragment their overall message and dilute the persuasive impact of the arguments advocating for departure from the EU. While acknowledging that a diversity of opinion is typically a hallmark of a healthy democracy, he cautioned that the current fragmented landscape within the 'Leave' movement specifically risked confusing voters and inadvertently playing into the hands of those who wished to remain within the European Union. For the 'Leave' campaign to achieve success, he contended that it required absolute clarity of purpose, a laser-like focus on the foundational arguments for national sovereignty and economic opportunity, and critically, a cohesive and disciplined leadership capable of speaking with one unified voice. Crucially, it needed to be perceived by the public as a truly unified force, rather than merely a collection of warring factions. His earnest hope was that by removing himself from the immediate leadership structure, it might thereby create a vital opportunity for a renewed and stronger focus on unity and strategic coherence within the campaign. He affirmed that his personal commitment to seeing Britain leave the European Union remained absolute, and he would continue to support the broader 'Leave' cause, albeit from outside this specific leadership role. He concluded by wishing the campaign every success in the vital months ahead, underscoring that the stakes for the nation were incredibly high, and it was therefore imperative that the 'Leave' side presented an irrefutable case for a brighter, independent future for the United Kingdom.

Type_2:
Star Randel - Hanson killed Derick Marney , 70 , at a flat in Vernon Terrace , Brighton , in May 2015 . He broke down and confessed to the murder 10 days later he went to tarot reader Jayne Braiden on Brighton seafront . She alerted police but was told it was a " non - emergency " so she waited an hour with the killer for an officer to come . Ms Braiden told BBC Radio 5 Live : " By the time we had waited an hour, with the police still seemingly not grasping the urgency of the situation, I was frantic. Star Randel-Hanson was sitting there, surprisingly calm, almost relieved, having just admitted to a murder. I couldn't believe they treated it as a 'non-emergency'! I called again, pleading for an officer to attend immediately, emphasizing the confession to Derick Marney's death."

She described how, after what felt like an eternity, two officers finally arrived at the Brighton seafront. Star Randel-Hanson offered no resistance and was taken into custody. Police quickly confirmed that 70-year-old Derick Marney had indeed been found dead at his flat in Vernon Terrace, Brighton, in May 2015. Randel-Hanson's detailed confession to Ms Braiden proved to be a critical piece of evidence, swiftly leading to his formal charge for Derick Marney's murder.

During the subsequent trial at Lewes Crown Court, the prosecution detailed the brutal nature of Mr Marney's death, revealing Randel-Hanson's 'unhealthy obsession' with the victim, leading to the fatal confrontation at the Vernon Terrace property. Despite defence arguments concerning his mental state, the jury found Star Randel-Hanson guilty of murder. His confession to Jayne Braiden on the Brighton seafront was deemed reliable and crucial to the conviction.

Star Randel-Hanson was handed a life sentence for the murder of Derick Marney. The judge condemned his actions, highlighting the profound impact on Derick Marney's family. The case underscored the vital role played by Jayne Braiden, whose persistence, despite initial police delays, ensured a confessed killer was apprehended and brought to justice. Her actions were pivotal in solving the murder that occurred in Vernon Terrace, Brighton, bringing closure to a tragic event.

Type_2: The swoon weighed on US markets , offsetting gains in financial and energy stocks . The tech - heavy Nasdaq index fell 113.84 points or 1.80%% to 6,207.92 . The broader S&P 500 dipped 2.02 points or 0.08 % to 2,431.77 , while the Dow Jones edged up 89.44 points , rising 0.42 % to 21,271.97 . US markets had seen limited movement earlier this week . The sharp downturn in the tech-heavy Nasdaq was largely attributed to burgeoning political uncertainty in Washington, particularly stemming from recent developments in the ongoing FBI investigation into the administration. This created a cautious sentiment among investors, leading to a significant sell-off in technology stocks, which disproportionately impacted the Nasdaq's performance. In contrast, the Dow Jones Industrial Average, with its lesser exposure to the technology sector, managed to post a gain, buoyed by strength in its financial and industrial components. The S&P 500's slight dip reflected the mixed performance across various sectors, where some gains, notably in energy and financials, partially offset the broader tech-led decline. Investors are now closely scrutinizing political headlines, as they appear to be driving market movements more significantly than economic data or corporate earnings. This shift in focus underscores a growing investor apprehension regarding potential political fallout. Across the Atlantic, the UK's FTSE 100 also experienced a modest decline, mirroring the global risk-off sentiment. The overall market mood indicates that political risks are increasingly weighing on US equity valuations, prompting a re-evaluation of portfolio strategies as the week concludes.

Type_2:
Andreea Cristea is the fifth victim of the attack on 22 March , in which Khalid Masood drove into crowds on Westminster Bridge then stabbed a policeman to death , before being shot dead himself . Ms Cristea , 31 , who was on holiday with boyfriend Andrei Burnaz , had been in hospital since the attack . It has emerged that Mr Burnaz had been planning to propose during the day out . A family statement confirmed Ms Cristea , who was an architect , had died on Thursday . The architect, who had been visiting London from Romania, was thrown into the River Thames during the rampage by Khalid Masood. She was rescued from the water but had suffered catastrophic head injuries and a severe lung infection, remaining in critical condition for weeks at St Thomas' Hospital. Her family, including her parents and sister, had maintained a constant vigil at her bedside, desperately hoping for her recovery, until her tragic passing.

Mr Burnaz, who sustained a fractured foot in the attack and has since undergone surgery, has spoken emotionally about the terrifying moments after they were hit and his desperate search for Andreea amidst the chaos. He described seeing Ms Cristea disappear into the water after being struck by the vehicle, and his frantic efforts to locate her before she was pulled out by rescuers. The couple, originally from Constana, Romania, were on a romantic trip, and the revelation that Mr Burnaz had intended to propose adds a profoundly tragic layer to their story, highlighting the dreams and future abruptly stolen by the act of terror.

Ms Cristea's death tragically brings the total number of fatalities directly resulting from Khalid Masood's attack to five. The other victims were US tourist Kurt Cochran, retired window cleaner Leslie Rhodes, and mother-of-two Aysha Frade, all of whom were struck on Westminster Bridge, along with PC Keith Palmer, the brave officer stabbed to death by Masood at the gates of the Palace of Westminster. The attack, which stunned the world, transformed a bustling London landmark into a scene of unimaginable horror and grief.

Tributes have poured in for Andreea, remembering her as a vibrant, talented architect with a promising future. The Romanian Ambassador to the UK expressed deep sorrow, conveying the shared grief of the Romanian community for her loss. Her tragic passing is a stark reminder of the global reach of such violence, impacting individuals from diverse backgrounds who were simply enjoying a day out in a major capital. The investigation into Masoods motives and potential associates continues, but the devastating human cost of his actions, epitomized by Ms Cristea and Mr Burnaz, remains the most poignant legacy. London, a city known for its enduring spirit and resilience, mourns its lost, but remains united against the hatred that seeks to divide it.

Britain 's world heavyweight champion apologised last month for a video he posted online containing homophobic , sexist and anti - Semitic comments . But ex - champion Klitschko , who fights Fury in Manchester on 9 July , said : " I was in shock at his statements . " When I heard about the video, I found it incredibly disturbing," the Ukrainian fighter continued, clearly upset. "As a professional athlete, you have a responsibility to be a role model. To use your platform for such hateful rhetoric, especially anti-Semitic comments that evoke dark periods of history, is simply unacceptable. It goes against everything sport should represent." Klitschko, himself from a nation that suffered immensely during World War II, expressed deep concern about the impact such statements could have.

Furys controversial remarks had drawn widespread condemnation across Britain, leading to calls for his license to be revoked. His anti-Semitic tirade, in which he claimed "Zionist, Jewish people... own all the banks, all the palaces, all the world," caused profound offence, echoing historical prejudices. His previous sexist and homophobic comments also resurfaced, painting a picture of ingrained bigotry. The Campaign Against Antisemitism, a prominent UK watchdog, was particularly vocal, calling for decisive action against the British boxer. They emphasized the danger of hateful speech from high-profile athletes, especially when it mirrors rhetoric associated with figures like Hitler, stressing the need for public figures to grasp the gravity of their words. Klitschko added, "This isn't just about boxing anymore. This is about basic human decency and respect." He stressed that while the fight was imminent, Furys actions had transcended the sport, raising serious questions about a champion's values. The immense backlash forced Fury to issue an apology, which many found insincere, only fueling the controversy.

The visitors closed on 293 - 9 at the end of day three , with a lead of 260 . Jacques Rudolph 's wait for a first Championship hundred in 2016 continued as he chopped onto his stumps for 56 . Earlier , Essex had been bowled out for 319 , with Craig Meschede ( 5 - 84 ) taking his first five - wicket haul in first-class cricket for Glamorgan. His accurate seam bowling ripped through the Essex middle order, claiming the crucial scalps of Simon Harmer and Neil Wagner as Essex were dismissed for 319. Earlier, Alastair Cook had made a patient 90, but Meschede's spell truly restricted Essex.

Glamorgan began their second innings with a 26-run deficit. Openers Nick Selman (41) and Jacques Rudolph built a steady platform. Rudolph, despite his eventual dismissal, looked largely untroubled for much of his 125-ball stay, striking seven boundaries. His uncharacteristic lapse saw him drag a delivery from Jamie Porter onto his stumps, ending his aspirations of a century. His departure at 110 for 2 brought Marnus Labuschagne (28) to the crease, who was then trapped lbw by Sam Cook. The Glamorgan middle order faced a testing period. Chris Cooke battled for his 35, and Kiran Carlson added 22, but wickets fell regularly as Essex bowlers exploited the variable bounce. A late cameo from Ryan Thomas, who hit a valuable 18 not out, helped extend the lead as the light faded. The visitors will hope their tailenders can add valuable runs on day four to set Essex a challenging target, with the pitch showing signs of wear and tear, promising more assistance for the spinners. Rudolph's earlier efforts, alongside Meschede's disciplined bowling, have put Glamorgan in a strong position, but the final day promises to be tense. The match remains finely poised, with Glamorgan holding the upper hand thanks to their consistent batting and Meschede's destructive spell.

Type_2:
Logan Murdoch suffered serious injuries in the crash and was not breathing when the Great North Air Ambulance team arrived . Hayley Murdoch , 29 , and Sheila Dixon , 71 , both from Carlisle , died following the collision at Newby Cross in 2016 . Dr Laura Duffy called Logan , years after that harrowing day, to marvel at his incredible journey back to health. She vividly recalled the scene at Newby Cross, describing it as one of the most challenging she had ever encountered. Logan had been clinically dead, but through the swift, coordinated efforts of the emergency services  the first responders, paramedics, and the air ambulance crew  he was resuscitated at the roadside. He was then airlifted to the Royal Victoria Infirmary in Newcastle in a critical condition, placed in an induced coma, and remained there for several weeks, fighting for his life. His family, already reeling from the devastating loss of Hayley Murdoch and Sheila Dixon, braced themselves for the worst, enduring agonizing days and nights by his bedside.

Against all odds, Logan began a slow, arduous recovery. Dr Duffy recounted the initial prognosis, which had been bleak, suggesting severe brain damage and long-term disability were highly probable. Yet, Logans resilience and determination, coupled with exceptional medical care, defied these expectations. His rehabilitation was extensive, involving months of physiotherapy, speech therapy, and psychological support to help him come to terms with the traumatic event and the profound grief of losing his mother and grandmother. The call from Dr Duffy was a poignant reminder of how close he came to joining them. She told him that his survival was nothing short of miraculous, a testament to the life-saving work done in those critical moments at the crash site near Carlisle. Logan, now a vocal advocate for the Great North Air Ambulance, often reflects on that day, acknowledging that without their rapid response, he would not be here today to share his story or remember his beloved Hayley Murdoch and Sheila Dixon. The scars, both physical and emotional, remain, but so does an immense gratitude for the second chance at life he received.

Type_2:
Stefan Appleton , 18 , was with friends when he was attacked in Nightingale Park in Islington on 10 June last year . The killer stabbed him with the 25 in ( 63 cm ) serrated blade after leaping off a stolen moped , the Old Bailey heard . The 17 - year - old , who can not be named due to his age , was cleared of murder . He will be sentenced on 21 April . Mr Appleton , a popular and bright teenager, was an avid football fan and a beloved son and brother. His death sent shockwaves through the Islington community, leaving his family and friends devastated. He was described by those who knew him as a joyful and kind-hearted individual with a promising future ahead of him. The brutal nature of the attack, carried out in a public park, deeply rattled local residents and intensified concerns about knife crime among young people.

The Metropolitan Police launched a comprehensive investigation, meticulously gathering evidence and tracking down the perpetrator. Detectives worked tirelessly to piece together the events leading up to the fatal stabbing. The court heard how the assailant, riding a stolen moped, had pursued Stefan before cornering him in Nightingale Park, close to the area often referred to as the Red Pitch, a popular local recreation spot. The ferocity of the attack, involving a large serrated blade, was a key focus of the prosecutions case.

During the trial at the Old Bailey, the prosecution argued that the defendant had demonstrated a clear intent to cause serious harm, if not death. However, the defence presented arguments challenging the specific intent required for a murder conviction, leading to the jurys decision to clear the 17-year-old of murder, finding him guilty of manslaughter instead. This verdict, while acknowledging the defendants responsibility for Stefans death, has been met with mixed emotions by Stefans family, who had campaigned tirelessly for justice. They issued a statement expressing their profound grief and the permanent void left by Stefans passing, but also reiterated their commitment to advocating for an end to knife violence.

The sentencing hearing on 21 April will determine the consequences for the teenager who took Stefans life. The case has highlighted the urgent need for interventions to prevent similar tragedies and to address the root causes of youth violence in London. Stefan Appletons legacy, though tragically cut short, continues to serve as a poignant reminder of the devastating impact of knife crime on individuals, families, and communities like Islington.

Court proceedings illustrated that Stefan was pursued by his assailant on a stolen moped, cornering him within Nightingale Park, specifically near the well-known recreational area called the Red Pitch. The prosecution emphasized both the extreme aggression of the assault and the use of such a large, serrated weapon.

During the Old Bailey trial, the prosecution asserted that the defendant intended to cause grievous bodily harm, if not death. However, the defense contested the specific level of intent necessary for a murder conviction, which ultimately led the jury to acquit the 17-year-old of murder but convict him of manslaughter. While this verdict confirms the defendant's responsibility for Stefans death, it was met with profound disappointment by Stefans family, who had earnestly sought a murder conviction to secure what they felt was justice. They issued a statement articulating their deep grief and the enduring void left by Stefans absence, while also reaffirming their steadfast commitment to campaigning against knife violence.

The upcoming sentencing on April 21 will determine the legal consequences for the teenager involved in Stefans demise. This case has powerfully underscored the urgent need for effective approaches to prevent similar tragedies and to tackle the underlying causes of youth violence across London. Although Stefan Appletons life was tragically cut short, his memory persists as a poignant reminder of the devastating impact of knife crime on victims, their grieving families, and entire communities like Islington.

Type_2: Lachlan returns to the Murdoch empire as co - chairman of News Corp and 21st Century Fox , having previously stood back to focus on his own businesses . Meanwhile , younger son James was appointed co - chief operating officer at 21st Century Fox . After the phone hacking scandal , which rocked the Murdoch empire and led to the closure of the News of the World, James Murdoch had faced intense scrutiny over his leadership at News International, the UK newspaper arm of News Corp. His reputation was significantly tarnished, and the controversy derailed 21st Century Fox's (then News Corporation's) bid to fully acquire BSkyB. This period was widely seen as a major crisis for the family business, leading ultimately to the dramatic split of the old News Corporation into two distinct entities: the new News Corp, housing the publishing assets, and 21st Century Fox, holding the more lucrative entertainment businesses. James's appointment as co-chief operating officer at 21st Century Fox, alongside his brother's elevated role, signaled a strategic shift by Rupert Murdoch to solidify the succession plan and perhaps rehabilitate James's image within the company's more profitable divisions. Despite the prior setbacks, the move demonstrated Rupert's enduring trust in his sons to steer the future of the vast media conglomerate, marking a crucial transition as Lachlan and James increasingly took on operational control, preparing for Rupert's eventual step back. The focus on entertainment under 21st Century Fox allowed for a clear demarcation from the historical issues associated with News Corp's beleaguered newspaper division, aiming to project a fresh, forward-looking image for the company's global media ambitions.

Type_2: 6 October 2016 Last updated at 16:36 BST More than 500 students in South Africa have joined nationwide protests over rising university fees, according to reports monitored by BBC Africa, continuing a movement that began earlier this October.
Type_5_1st: By 16:36 BST on October 6, 2016, over 500 South African students had joined nationwide protests against rising university tuition, according to BBC Africa. This extends a movement that began earlier this month.
Type_5_3rd: BBC Africa noted that by 16:36 BST on October 6, 2016, over 500 South African students were involved in national demonstrations opposing higher university tuition, building on a movement initiated earlier that month.

Type_2: The Caerau hill fort near Ely is thought to have been occupied from the 5th Century BC by the Silurian tribe . A dig last year involving 1,000 people found its use may have been far more extensive and continuous than previously understood, serving as a vital strategic stronghold for the Silurian tribe for centuries. The ambitious project, led by renowned archaeologist Professor Olly Davis, was a testament to community archaeology, involving 1,000 dedicated volunteers last year who unearthed compelling evidence. Discoveries included sophisticated defensive structures, extensive domestic dwellings, and a wealth of Iron Age artefacts, painting a vivid picture of a thriving, resilient community that played a pivotal role in the Silurians' resistance against Roman expansion in South Wales. This remarkable dig has significantly reshaped our understanding of this historically important site, demonstrating its enduring significance not just as a fort, but as a vibrant centre of life and culture in ancient South Wales.

Type_2: Up to 40,000 people and 140 bands took part in the march , which is the largest loyal order demonstration in Northern Ireland . Three people have been arrested for public order offences . The event began with a parade around the city 's historic walls and then proceeded to The Diamond in the city centre where thousands gathered for a rallying call and speeches. Prominent figures from various loyal orders addressed the crowds, emphasizing the importance of their heritage and traditions in Northern Ireland. The atmosphere was largely peaceful, although the earlier arrests highlighted the need for continued vigilance by the PSNI. The main demonstration featured a service of remembrance and thanksgiving, with many participants later attending a special service at nearby St. Columb's Cathedral, a significant landmark within the walled city. Among those speaking at the central gathering were Grand Master Jim Brownlee, who reiterated the loyal orders' commitment to their culture and community, and Mark McEwan, a local organiser, who thanked participants for their respectful conduct. The event, commemorating historical events central to the loyalist identity, reaffirmed the enduring presence of these traditions in the fabric of Northern Ireland.

Armed troops are already being deployed to protect key locations such as Buckingham Palace , Downing Street and embassies to free up police officers . It comes after the bomb attack at Manchester Arena on Monday which killed 22 people , some as young as eight . London mayor Sadiq Khan said security experts were advising event organisers . He said there was " no reason to be alarmed or to panic , this is a prudent course to take " . Bomber ' likely ' to have had a network, Greater Manchester Police confirmed. Salman Ramadan Abedi, 22, the identified suicide bomber, was known to security services. Investigations continue, with several arrests made. Assistant Chief Constable Debra Plaice said focus remained on Manchester, but police nationwide, including the Met Police, were reviewing security.

Prime Minister Theresa May raised the UK's terror threat to 'critical', meaning an imminent attack. Up to 3,800 troops will support armed police. Soldiers guarding prominent London landmarks free up thousands of armed officers for other duties, including public events and transport hubs.

Met Police Commissioner Cressida Dick said the public would see more armed officers. "We will be out there in greater numbers," she stated, reiterating Sadiq Khan's message for vigilance, not panic. Commissioner Dick confirmed Operation Temperer, military aid to civil power, was in effect.

Mayor Sadiq Khan addressed Londoners, condemning the "evil and cowardly" Manchester attack and expressing condolences. He urged unity and resilience, asking people not to let terrorists divide them. Khan confirmed specific advice for major event organisers in the capital, including upcoming football finals and concerts, on enhancing security. "Our police and security services are working tirelessly," Khan stated, urging reports of anything suspicious. "The greatest act of defiance against terrorism is to carry on with our lives, safely and securely."

Heightened security follows the Manchester Arena bombing which killed 22, including eight-year-old Saffie-Rose Roussos. The complex investigation seeks Abedi's full support network. Police raids continue in Manchester, with further arrests anticipated. The Met Police are actively involved in national counter-terrorism coordination and intelligence sharing.
