Type_2:
In 2014 , Kim Lennon said the smuggling of drugs was rife at Lewes Prison and its wings " resembled a war zone " . She was dismissed earlier this week following disciplinary proceedings but said she would appeal and had no regrets about speaking out . The Ministry of Justice ( MoJ ) said Ms Lennon was not dismissed for being a whistleblower . ' The Ministry of Justice (MoJ) maintained that Ms Lennons dismissal was the result of a comprehensive internal disciplinary process, unconnected to her claims regarding prison conditions. A spokesperson for the MoJ stated that all prison staff are expected to adhere to the highest standards, and where these are not met, disciplinary action will be taken. Citing employee confidentiality, they would not discuss specific details of Ms Lennon's case, but reaffirmed the decision followed a thorough investigation into her conduct, concluding that her actions constituted serious breaches of policy.

Kim Lennon, however, strongly refuted the MoJs narrative, asserting that the disciplinary charges against her were a deliberate attempt to discredit her and suppress vital information about the critical state of Lewes Prison. She told reporters that her complaints, made over an extended period, had consistently been met with insufficient action by management. "I reported serious instances of drug dealing, violence, and a complete lack of control, which put both staff and inmates at immense risk," Ms Lennon stated. "Instead of addressing these grave issues, the prison management chose to target me. They wanted to silence anyone brave enough to speak the truth about a system that is failing drastically." She highlighted that the current measures by the Ministry of Justice were clearly insufficient to tackle the deep-rooted problems within the prison.

Ms Lennons case brings to light the ongoing challenges faced by the MoJ in managing the escalating problem of drug smuggling and violence within the UK's prison estate. Independent oversight bodies and parliamentary committees have repeatedly raised concerns about the scale of the issue, with reports frequently citing staff shortages, overcrowding, and a lack of resources as contributing factors. Critics argue that the government's response to these systemic failures has been inadequate, leaving frontline officers like Kim Lennon vulnerable when they attempt to expose dangerous realities.

The former officer intends to take her case to an employment tribunal, where she hopes to present evidence not only of wrongful dismissal but also of the dire conditions she witnessed. "My appeal isn't just about my job; it's about exposing the truth for the safety of everyone inside those walls," said Ms Lennon, vowing to continue her fight regardless of the personal cost. She remains steadfast in her belief that the public has a right to know the true state of affairs within their prisons, and that the MoJ must be held accountable for its duty of care. Her legal team is currently preparing the documentation, confident that they can demonstrate that Ms Lennon was unfairly targeted for her whistleblowing activities. The case is expected to draw significant attention to the broader debate around transparency and accountability within the prison system.

Type_2:
That is according to new figures from Northern Ireland Screen , which has provided production funding for the HBO series . The programme , some of which is filmed in Northern Ireland , has been nominated for 24 Emmy awards . Two of those nominations are for Northern Ireland production crew members . Ronan Hill , who won an Emmy in 2012 , has been nominated again for outstanding sound mixing for a drama , while Carla Stronge has been nominated for outstanding casting for the widely acclaimed HBO series. These nominations highlight the immense talent within Northern Ireland's thriving screen industry and underscore the region's growing reputation as a global hub for film and television production. The significant investment from Northern Ireland Screen, an agency dedicated to promoting the film, television, and animation industry, has been instrumental in attracting major international productions like this HBO series to the region. This strategic funding not only provides essential financial support but also helps to develop a robust infrastructure and a highly skilled local workforce, ensuring that Northern Ireland remains a competitive and attractive location for high-profile projects.

The success of the programme, with its impressive 24 Emmy nominations, serves as a powerful testament to the collaborative efforts of international studios and local talent. It demonstrates the depth of expertise available in Northern Ireland, from sound engineering and casting to set design and visual effects. The recognition of Ronan Hill, a multiple Emmy winner, and Carla Stronge, a prominent figure in casting, particularly emphasizes the world-class skills present within the Northern Ireland production community. Their individual achievements reflect the high standards maintained across all facets of the production.

Richard Williams, Chief Executive of Northern Ireland Screen, expressed immense pride in the nominations, stating, "We are absolutely thrilled to see the exceptional work of our local crew members recognised on such a prestigious international stage. Ronan and Carla's nominations are thoroughly deserved and shine a spotlight on the incredible talent pool we have here in Northern Ireland. The continued success of this HBO series, parts of which are meticulously filmed across our beautiful landscapes, showcases the immense value that our region brings to global entertainment. Our commitment to fostering and supporting the indigenous screen industry continues to pay dividends, attracting inward investment, creating jobs, and enhancing our reputation worldwide."

The filming of parts of the series in Northern Ireland has brought considerable economic benefits, including significant spending in the local economy on services, accommodation, and local businesses, as well as providing extensive employment opportunities for hundreds of crew members and ancillary staff. This ongoing success story reinforces the long-term vision of Northern Ireland Screen to build a sustainable and vibrant creative sector, capable of delivering world-class content and competing on the global stage. The upcoming Emmy Awards ceremony will undoubtedly be a moment of great anticipation for everyone involved, particularly for the dedicated Northern Ireland team who have contributed so much to the show's artistic excellence and popular appeal. The impact of such high-profile productions extends beyond mere economic figures, fostering a sense of pride and inspiring the next generation of filmmakers and creative professionals in the region. This pattern of sustained growth and international recognition firmly positions Northern Ireland as a key player in the global entertainment landscape, driven by its unique locations, skilled professionals, and proactive support from organisations like Northern Ireland Screen. The nominations serve as a clear indicator of the high calibre of work being produced and the bright future that lies ahead for the industry in the province.

Type_2:
The suspects are accused of smuggling large quantities of cocaine from Colombia to Europe in sailing boats . Officials said among those arrested is a commander of the Colombian left - wing rebel group , Farc . Police said the suspects were part of a transatlantic drugs ring run by the ' Ndrangheta a powerful organized crime syndicate based in Calabria, southern Italy. This operation highlights the growing partnership between Colombian drug producers, particularly remnant factions associated with the dissolved Farc insurgency, and the sophisticated distribution networks of European mafias. Investigators revealed that the cocaine shipments originated in remote jungle labs in Colombia, often in areas previously controlled by the Farc, who either directly cultivated coca or levied 'taxes' on independent producers for safe passage and processing.

The sailing boats were chosen for their ability to blend in with legitimate maritime traffic, making them less conspicuous than large cargo vessels, and for their capacity to carry substantial loads without attracting undue attention. The routes typically involved crossing the Atlantic, often utilizing strategically located island nations as re-provisioning points before reaching European ports, predominantly in Spain and Portugal, for onward distribution across the continent. This particular bust involved meticulous intelligence gathering over several years, a collaborative effort spanning multiple law enforcement agencies.

A significant breakthrough came with intelligence shared by The US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), which had been tracking the cartel's activities and its nexus with various Colombian narco-trafficking groups. Authorities in Colombia and Italy, alongside Europol and other European police forces, executed synchronized raids following the DEA's lead. Among the arrests were key logistical managers in Europe and several suppliers in South America. The Farc commander arrested in Colombia was reportedly a crucial link, responsible for ensuring the quality and quantity of the cocaine supplied and facilitating its transport to coastal rendezvous points. Further investigations are underway in the region, including in areas near Santa Fe, where some of the preliminary processing and logistics for the illicit drug trade are suspected to have taken place, demonstrating the intricate web of this criminal enterprise. The scale of the operation underscores the global reach of organized crime and the persistent challenge posed by the drug trade.

Type_2: A report has said uniting council departments with different responsibilities would help improve the town 's prospects . The strategy aims to reduce the number of empty shop units , increase visitors with more public events and reduce antisocial behaviour . Councillor Andrew Atkinson, a prominent figure in Wrexham's local government, has been a vocal advocate for this proposed restructuring. Atkinson argues that the current fragmented approach often leads to inefficiencies and missed opportunities, particularly in a town like Wrexham which is striving for significant regeneration. He pointed to the need for a unified vision that can tackle complex urban issues holistically. For instance, revitalising areas such as the People's Market requires coordinated efforts from departments responsible for planning, economic development, public safety, and cultural events. He envisions a future where council teams work seamlessly, pooling resources and expertise to deliver tangible improvements. This would not only enhance the aesthetic appeal of the town but also create a more vibrant and secure environment. By fostering a truly integrated approach, Atkinson believes Wrexham can overcome its challenges, attract new businesses, and cement its reputation as a thriving regional hub, benefiting residents and visitors alike through a more dynamic and prosperous town centre.

Type_2:
The statement from the firm came just days after it announced the sale of the Financial Times to Japan 's Nikkei . Pearson said it was in discussions regarding the sale of the Economist but there was " no certainty that this process will lead to a transaction ". This divestment of its print media holdings, including the iconic Financial Times, signals a clear strategic pivot for Pearson. The company, under CEO John Fallon, is increasingly focusing on its global education business, aiming to streamline its portfolio and concentrate resources on digital learning and assessment tools. This marks the end of an era for Pearson as a diversified media conglomerate, aligning with a broader industry trend of specialization.

The potential sale of its 50% stake in the Economist Group, which publishes the influential weekly magazine, presents a more intricate challenge. Unlike the straightforward acquisition of the Financial Times by Japan's Nikkei, the Economist has a unique ownership structure designed to safeguard its editorial independence. A trust holds a significant portion of shares, and a consortium of long-standing family shareholders  including the Rothschilds, Cadburys, and Schroders, alongside Italy's powerful Agnelli family through their investment vehicle Exor  own the remaining stakes. John Elkann, chairman of Exor, had publicly expressed interest in increasing their shareholding, emphasizing their commitment to maintaining the publication's journalistic integrity and distinct ethos.

This inherent complexity, requiring consensus among existing shareholders deeply invested in the Economist's long-term vision, explains Pearson's cautious statement regarding "no certainty." For Pearson, completing these divestitures would solidify its identity as a pure-play education company, allowing it to dedicate all efforts to developing digital learning platforms globally and capitalize on the evolving education sector. These moves underscore the significant redefinition underway in the media and publishing industries.

The star of How I Met Your Mother and Gone Girl will host 10 episodes of the variety show for NBC , according to the Hollywood Reporter . Harris called the show , created by British TV presenting duo Ant McPartlin and Declan Donnelly , " a fantastic opportunity to bring a fresh, modern take on the classic variety show format to American audiences. Its a genre Ive always loved and respected, and the chance to reinvent it with a team as talented as this, led by the brilliant Ant and Dec, is truly exciting."

Harris, known for his charismatic stage presence and versatile talentsspanning acting, singing, dancing, and even magicis considered a natural fit for the demanding role. His extensive experience hosting major awards shows like the Academy Awards, Tony Awards, and Emmy Awards has solidified his reputation as a master of ceremonies capable of engaging large audiences with his wit and charm. The new NBC series, which is expected to blend celebrity interviews, musical performances, sketches, games, and audience participation, aims to recreate the magic of live television that has been a hallmark of classic variety shows while infusing it with a contemporary sensibility. Type_2: The 24 - year - old , who can not be named until he enters his plea , is accused of raping the teenager in the toilets of a bar in Johannesburg . Earlier in the week , the family of the alleged victim said that Mr Mandela , widely believed to be a grandson of the late Nelson Mandela, had been identified to them as the perpetrator. While the 24-year-old cannot be officially named by the media until he enters his plea, the victim's family has expressed their profound distress and called for swift justice. They confirmed that they had reached out to members of the broader Mandela family, including Makaziwe Mandela, for support in this sensitive matter. A spokesperson for the family indicated that they felt a moral obligation from the Mandela lineage, historically associated with fighting for justice, to address the serious allegations. The BBC has learned that while no formal statement has been issued by the Mandela family, sources close to Winnie Madikizela-Mandela's descendants have privately conveyed their deep concern over the incident in Johannesburg and stated they are awaiting the due process of law. The case continues to attract significant public and media interest across South Africa.

Type_2: Members of Braintree 's Dolphin Women 's Institute ( WI ) have stitched some of the town 's best - known landmarks including the church and museum . Each model is about 45 cm ( 18 in ) tall and was created using a polystyrene or cardboard core with knitting sewn on Each model is about 45 cm (18 in) tall and was created using a polystyrene or cardboard core with knitting sewn on. This ambitious Dolphin Women's Institute project aimed to capture Braintree's unique character through miniature landmarks. Initiated during lockdowns, it offered members a creative outlet and shared goal. Led by talented Elaine Pye, a long-standing member and avid knitter, the group focused on iconic structures defining Braintree's heritage. Beyond the meticulously crafted church and museum, other notable additions include the historic town hall, vibrant market square, and a miniature old railway station, each brought to life with incredible detail. The intricate process involved members dedicating countless hours to knitting specific textures and colours for each building's facade, windows, and roofs. Completed knitted sections were then carefully cut and sewn onto prepared cores, ensuring a perfect fit and realistic appearance. The precision for these miniature architectural marvels is truly impressive. Elaine Pye, known for her intricate textile art, guided the team through challenging aspects, sharing techniques and encouraging collaborative work. This dedication has resulted in a unique exhibition celebrating both the town's history and the incredible crafting skills within the Dolphin Women's Institute. The completed collection is set to be displayed at various community events and local venues across Braintree throughout the coming months, starting with an inaugural viewing at the Braintree Museum. This public display will allow residents and visitors alike to appreciate the intricate workmanship and recognise their beloved town in a brand new, whimsical format. The project has fostered community among WI members and generated considerable local interest, drawing praise for its originality and charm. The Dolphin Women's Institute hopes this unique collection will inspire others, serving as a delightful testament to their creativity and commitment to enriching local life. While primarily focused on Braintree, the project's success has even garnered attention from neighbouring WI groups, with some Hertfordshire members expressing interest in similar initiatives.

This affords both local residents and visitors a wonderful opportunity to admire the elaborate craftsmanship and view their cherished town in a fresh, endearing light. The undertaking has successfully strengthened bonds among WI members and generated significant local enthusiasm, earning praise for its originality and charm.

The Dolphin Women's Institute hopes this unique display will serve as an inspiration to others, standing as a delightful testament to their ingenuity and dedication to enhancing local community life. Although primarily focused on Braintree, the project's success has also attracted interest from adjacent WI groups, with some members in Hertfordshire expressing a desire to embark on similar creative ventures.

Type_2:
A total of 374 employees lost their jobs when Tullis Russell Papermakers , based at Markinch in Fife , went into administration in April 2015 . Each employee received the equivalent of eight weeks ' wages in compensation for their loss . The award follows a judgement from an employment tribunal in Dundee, handed down earlier this year. The tribunal's decision found that Tullis Russell Papermakers, a company with a rich history stretching back over 200 years in Markinch, Fife, had failed to properly consult its employees and their union representatives on the mass redundancies before the company's collapse. This failure to adhere to the statutory obligation for collective consultation under the Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992, meant that workers were entitled to a protective award.

The case was spearheaded by former employees who sought justice for the abrupt and devastating job losses. David Martyn, a partner and specialist in employment law at the Dundee office of the law firm Gilson Gray LLP (formerly part of Bond Pearce, which was acquired), played a pivotal role in representing the affected workers. Martyn welcomed the tribunals finding, stating that it offered some measure of vindication and financial relief to the hundreds of individuals and families severely impacted by the mill's closure. He highlighted the importance of employers, even those facing insolvency, upholding their legal duties towards their workforce during redundancy processes.

The closure of Tullis Russell, a cornerstone of industry in Markinch and the wider Fife region, sent shockwaves through the community, marking the end of an era for papermaking in the area and leaving a significant void in the local economy. For the 374 employees, many of whom had dedicated decades of their working lives to the mill, the compensation, although limited to eight weeks' pay, provided essential support during a period of immense uncertainty and hardship. This protective award serves as a critical reminder of workers' rights during such challenging corporate transitions, ensuring that even in administration, companies are held accountable for their legal obligations concerning workforce redundancy.

Type_2:
The move follows a rise in the number of oil and gas operators using unmanned aerial systems ( UAS ) to conduct inspections and other offshore tasks . The guidelines were developed by industry and aviation safety experts and UAS operators . They provide comprehensive and clear guidance for safe and efficient UAS operations across the UK offshore energy sector. These guidelines cover critical areas such as operational planning, risk assessment, personnel competency, equipment standards, and emergency response procedures, aiming to standardize practices and significantly enhance overall safety. The increasing use of UAS offers substantial benefits for the industry, including improved safety by reducing the need for personnel in hazardous environments, cost efficiencies through faster data collection, and enhanced asset integrity management.

Mick Borwell, Environment Director at OEUK, played a pivotal role in this collaborative effort. Mr. Borwell highlighted that these new guidelines are essential for integrating UAS technology responsibly and effectively into daily offshore tasks. He emphasized that the primary goal is to ensure that while the industry embraces technological advancements, safety remains paramount. The comprehensive nature of these guidelines will enable operators to maximize the advantages of UAS while adhering to robust safety standards, fostering best practices, and ensuring regulatory compliance within the UK's offshore sector.

Type_2:
Kathryn Smith said she received 52 a week in income support , some of which was used to buy the Class B substance . Jurors previously heard she was concerned 21 - month - old Ayeeshia Jane Smith may have had a seizure after taking drugs kept at the house . Ms Smith and ex - partner Matthew Rigby both deny murder . More on this and other stories from Stoke and Staffordshire The toddler , known as AJ , died in 2014 at the family home in St Giles Road, Burton-upon-Trent, following what the prosecution described as a "terrible assault". The court heard that AJ suffered "catastrophic" injuries, including a lacerated heart and internal bleeding, consistent with a severe impact. Post-mortem examinations revealed that Ayeeshia Jane Smith also had historic injuries, including a previous brain bleed and fractures to her ribs, consistent with her having been subjected to non-accidental harm on more than one occasion before her death.

Opening the prosecution's case, Christopher Hotten QC told the jury that both Ms Smith, 23, and Matthew Rigby, 21, were responsible for the fatal injuries inflicted upon AJ. He alleged that the couple, who were in a volatile relationship, had engaged in a "joint enterprise" to inflict serious harm, or that one had caused the injuries while the other failed to protect the child. The jury was presented with evidence of a chaotic household where drug use, including cannabis, was prevalent. Ms Smith's admission about using her limited income support to fund drug purchases underlined the difficult environment AJ was living in. The prosecution highlighted texts and calls between Ms Smith and Rigby in the hours leading up to AJ's death, which painted a picture of tension and concern about AJ's health, specifically the worry that she may have ingested drugs.

During cross-examination, Ms Smith maintained her innocence, accusing Matthew Rigby of being the one who inflicted the fatal injuries. She claimed she had briefly left the room and returned to find AJ unresponsive. Conversely, Rigby's defence team argued that it was Ms Smith who was responsible, suggesting she had a history of losing her temper and being violent. The court heard conflicting accounts from both defendants, each attempting to shift blame onto the other. Social services had been involved with the family prior to AJ's death, and concerns about the child's welfare had been raised on multiple occasions. Evidence presented included records of these interventions and assessments. The trial, presided over by Mr Justice Haddon-Cave at Stafford Crown Court, continues to hear from medical experts, police officers, and other witnesses who were involved in the investigation. The jury's task is to determine who was responsible for the tragic death of Ayeeshia Jane Smith, considering the complex web of evidence and conflicting narratives presented by the defence and prosecution. The deeply distressing nature of the case, involving a young child, has drawn significant public attention to the proceedings.

Type_2: The four bedroom Georgian home provided the setting where eight - year - old Kevin McCallister , played by Macauley Culkin , outwitted a pair of bungling burglers . The film earned more than $ 477 m worldwide, equating to over 291 million, solidifying its place as a holiday classic. The iconic Georgian residence, central to Kevin McCallisters ingenious traps and escapades, was not custom-built for the movie but was a real family home located in Winnetka, Illinois. This distinctive property, instantly recognizable to fans, served as the primary set for many of Macauley Culkins memorable scenes as the resourceful young protagonist. For decades, the house has been owned by John and Cynthia Abendshien, who graciously allowed their private residence to be transformed into the McCallister family home for the duration of filming. They have often recounted stories of the filming process, particularly how the production team worked around their family life, even using parts of their home for crew facilities. The enduring appeal of the film continues to draw curious onlookers to the quiet suburban street, eager to catch a glimpse of the house where Kevin McCallister famously defended his turf against the Wet Bandits, forever linking the stately architecture with the timeless tale of a boy's unexpected holiday adventure.

Type_2:
Hank Costain , 88 , from Charminster , near Dorchester , first flew a Spitfire in 1942 , at the age of 19 . The maiden flight of the Supermarine Spitfire took place on 5 March 1936 , from Eastleigh Aerodrome , now Southampton Airport . Mr Costain described flying a Spitfire as " absolutely marvellous " . He said : " When you first got into the seat and opened the throttle it felt as if someone had given you a good kick up the backside. The roar of the Merlin engine was deafening, a symphony of power that vibrated through every fibre of the airframe, and indeed, through my very bones. It wasn't just a machine; it was an extension of yourself, a living, breathing entity that responded to every subtle command.

The Spitfire was incredibly responsive, light on the controls despite its formidable power. Once airborne, the world transformed. Below, the patchwork fields and familiar landmarks of Dorset shrunk into a vast, detailed map. Above, the sky was an endless canvas, and in that moment, you felt utterly free, completely at one with the machine and the elements. Wed practice aerobatics, pushing the limits, feeling the G-forces press us into our seats as we banked sharply or pulled up into a loop. There was a sense of incredible exhilaration, a rush that I don't think anything else could ever truly replicate.

He recounted his initial training with a mix of fondness and the stark realism of wartime preparation. Learning to fly the Supermarine Spitfire wasnt just about mastering controls; it was about understanding its character. Each one had its own quirks, its own personality. You had to respect it, and it would look after you. He remembered the intense pressure, the long hours in the cockpit, and the relentless drills designed to turn young men into formidable combat pilots. The sheer speed and agility of the aircraft, especially compared to the training planes, was astounding. It was a revelation, a technological marvel that put Britain at the forefront of aerial warfare.

For Mr Costain, the Spitfire was more than just an aircraft; it was a symbol of an era, a machine that played a pivotal role in shaping the course of history. It saved us, didnt it? he mused, his eyes distant as if replaying old memories. It was the best fighter aircraft in the world, and we knew it. Every time you took off, you felt that immense responsibility, but also an incredible pride. He often returns to airshows, his gaze fixed on the familiar silhouette of a Spitfire performing graceful loops and dives, a ghost of his youth soaring through the modern sky. The sound of its engine still brings a lump to his throat, a powerful echo of a time when courage and ingenuity defined a generation. Even now, decades later, the memory of those flights remains vividly etched in his mind, a testament to the profound impact that the Supermarine Spitfire had on his life and the lives of countless others.

It was a revelation, a technological marvel that positioned Britain at the forefront of aerial conflict.

To Mr. Costain, the Spitfire represented far more than just an airplane; it embodied an entire era, a machine instrumental in altering the trajectory of history. It ensured our survival, didn't it? he mused, his gaze distant, seemingly lost in past recollections. It was universally acknowledged as the finest fighter aircraft globally. He often visits airshows, his vision following the distinctive silhouette of a Spitfire as it executes elegant loops and descents, a moving reminder of his early life soaring across contemporary skies. The distinctive thrum of its engine continues to stir deep feelings, a powerful evocation of a time marked by bravery and innovation. Even after numerous decades, the memories of those flights persist with striking clarity, highlighting the deep influence the Supermarine Spitfire exerted on his personal journey and on innumerable others.

Type_2:
As many as 23 civilians were killed in the raid on a village in Yakla district on Saturday , including 10 children , rights group Reprieve says . Yemeni reports say the victims included the daughter of Anwar al - Awlaki , a militant killed by a US strike in 2011 . The raid was the first such operation authorised by President Donald Trump . The US military had previously said a Navy Seal , William " Ryan " Owens , 36 , died and three others were wounded. The Pentagon asserted the operation targeted al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and yielded significant intelligence, calling it a successful mission. However, these claims were swiftly countered by Yemeni officials and human rights organizations, who reported a much higher civilian death toll and questioned the mission's efficacy and planning.

Reprieve, a UK-based human rights group, stated that its ground investigators confirmed the deaths of at least 23 civilians, including 10 children, in the Yakla raid. Among the child victims was eight-year-old Nawar al-Awlaki, daughter of the American-Yemeni cleric Anwar al-Awlaki, who was himself killed in a US drone strike in 2011. Her family confirmed her death, sparking further outrage and highlighting the complex human cost of counter-terrorism operations in Yemen. Local reports indicated widespread destruction, with houses damaged and several civilians caught in the crossfire.

The high civilian casualty count and the death of a US serviceman immediately put the raid under intense scrutiny, particularly as it was the first authorized military action of President Trump's administration. Critics, including some US lawmakers, raised concerns about the intelligence used to approve the mission and its execution. Senator John McCain, then chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, initially described the mission as a "failure" due to the loss of life, though he later softened his stance. The US military launched an investigation into the civilian casualties amidst persistent questions about the tactical success and strategic implications of the operation in Yakla, al-Bayda province.

Rodriguez opened the scoring with a close - range header from Kieran Trippier 's cross after three minutes . Having missed a penalty , awarded for Garath McCleary 's foul on Ben Mee , Rodriguez then headed his second from another Trippier cross . On - loan Wolves man Adlene Guedioura went closest for the visitors, rattling the crossbar with a powerful long-range effort early in the second half. Despite their spirited efforts, Wolves struggled to find a way past Burnley's resolute defence, marshalled expertly by Ben Mee. The home side, buoyed by Rodriguez's brace, controlled much of the possession in the midfield, with Trippier continuing to be a menace down the right flank, his delivery a constant threat.

Burnleys dominance was evident, and they continued to press for a third goal to put the game beyond doubt. Scott Arfield and George Boyd worked tirelessly on the wings, creating space for the full-backs to push forward. Trippier, in particular, seemed to be enjoying one of his most influential performances of the season, his crosses causing panic in the Wolves penalty area time and again. However, Wolves goalkeeper Carl Ikeme pulled off several key saves to deny Burnley further additions to the scoreline, including a superb stop from a fierce Rodriguez volley that would have completed his hat-trick.

As the game wore on, Wolves pushed higher, desperate to find a goal that would reignite their hopes. Garath McCleary, who had been involved in the early penalty incident, tried to make amends with some penetrating runs, but his efforts were largely isolated. Burnleys backline, with Mee at its heart, stood firm against the late pressure. Manager Sean Dyche made tactical substitutions to shore up the midfield and defence, bringing on fresh legs to maintain their high work rate. The final whistle blew with Burnley securing a comfortable 2-0 victory, a result that reflected their superior attacking prowess and defensive solidity. Rodriguez's clinical finishing, combined with Kieran Trippier's exceptional service, proved to be the decisive factors in a commanding performance by the Clarets. The win saw Burnley climb further up the Championship table, consolidating their position as serious promotion contenders. Wolves, meanwhile, were left to ponder a missed opportunity on the road.

It is understood the Hammers will raise their offer for the player who began his career at the east London club . Defoe , 34 , has scored 11 goals in 21 appearances for the Premier League strugglers this season . His latest goals came on Monday as Sunderland twice fought from a goal deficit to draw 2-2 with Liverpool at the Stadium of Light. Defoe's two penalties highlighted his undiminished quality and vital importance to David Moyes' struggling side. Despite their precarious Premier League position, Sunderland are resolute in their stance that Defoe is not for sale. Moyes has repeatedly emphasized that losing their prolific scorer would severely jeopardise their survival hopes, particularly given how indispensable he has been to their attack.

West Ham's pursuit, however, remains persistent. Manager Slaven Bilic is keen to secure a proven goalscorer, as the Hammers have suffered from inconsistent attacking performances and injuries this season. Bringing a player of Defoe's calibre and Premier League experience back to the London Stadium is seen as a key move to bolster their ambitions. The reported increased offer from the east London club is said to be around 6 million, but Sunderland are understood to value him considerably higher, closer to 10-12 million, reflecting his irreplaceable status. Defoe himself has maintained focus on his on-field commitments, embodying dedication to the Black Cats. His current priority is unequivocally keeping Sunderland in the top flight, a monumental task he has largely spearheaded. This transfer saga is expected to continue until the window closes, with West Ham anticipated to test Sunderland's resolve further, even as the Black Cats stand firm on their 'not for sale' position regarding their talisman.

Type_2: Senioli , a scrum - half for Italian side Treviso pointed and smiled at Scott Williams , who plays for Welsh team Scarlets , as he ran towards the line during a crucial game in Italy . It should have been an easy try , but the Wales international , known for his relentless defensive work and never-say-die attitude, launched himself forward with a desperate lunge. The stadium, filled with passionate Italian fans roaring for Treviso, held its breath as Williams, defying the odds, somehow managed to get a hand to Senioli's ankle just inches from the try-line. The Treviso player stumbled, his momentum broken, and the ball, which he had been cradling loosely in anticipation of the score, was dislodged. It bounced once, tantalisingly close to the whitewash, before a Scarlets forward, arriving belatedly but opportunistically, dived on it, securing the turnover. The collective groan from the Italian crowd was almost as loud as the roar of relief from the small contingent of travelling Welsh supporters. Senioli, still sprawled on the turf, looked up in disbelief, the earlier smile replaced by a grimace of frustration. Scott Williams, quickly back on his feet, simply nodded, a silent testament to the high stakes of this cross-border encounter. This single moment, a testament to Williams's grit, shifted the momentum. Treviso, who had been dominating, suddenly looked rattled, while Scarlets, buoyed by the miraculous defensive stop, found a new surge of energy. The game, critical for both sides' European aspirations, hung finely in the balance, a true showcase of the intensity of rugby between Italy and Wales.

Type_2:
Writing in the Journal of Aesthetic Nursing , clinicians say there is a growing trend for under-25s to seek the wrinkle - smoothing injections . But the research suggests " frozen faces " could stop young people from learning how to express emotions fully . A leading body of UK plastic surgeons says injecting teenagers for cosmetic reasons is " morally wrong " . Botox and other versions of the toxin work by temporarily paralysing muscles in the upper face to reduce wrinkling when people frown . Nurse practitioner Helen Collier , who carried out the research , says reality TV and social media are significant drivers behind this worrying trend. She observed that many young clients are influenced by the flawless, often filter-enhanced, appearances portrayed online and in popular culture, leading to unrealistic expectations about their own looks. Ms Collier, whose findings are detailed in the Journal of Aesthetic Nursing, expressed particular concern about the psychological implications of intervening with a developing brain's ability to express and interpret emotions. She explained that the muscles targeted by Botox are crucial not only for frowning but also for conveying a wide range of human emotions, from surprise to sadness. If these muscles are routinely paralysed from an early age, it could hinder a young person's capacity to fully experience and communicate their feelings, potentially impacting their social development and emotional intelligence.

The research highlighted that while older patients often seek Botox to reverse visible signs of aging, younger individuals are increasingly opting for "preventative Botox," hoping to stop wrinkles from forming in the first place. This shift in motivation raises profound ethical questions for practitioners. Ms Collier argues that genuine informed consent is difficult to obtain from teenagers, whose brains are still developing, and who may not fully grasp the long-term consequences of such procedures. She emphasized that the decision to undergo a cosmetic procedure like Botox should be made maturely, weighing the risks and benefits, something many under-25s are not yet equipped to do.

The British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons (BAAPS), a leading body of UK plastic surgeons, has echoed these concerns, reiterating its strong stance against cosmetic injections for those under 18, deeming it "morally wrong." Even for those slightly older but still under 25, BAAPS advises extreme caution and thorough psychological assessment before any treatment. They advocate for a focus on mental well-being and body positivity rather than promoting interventions that can have irreversible impacts on a young person's self-perception and emotional development.

Ms Collier's research, published in the Journal of Aesthetic Nursing, urges clinicians to prioritize the mental health and developmental needs of young patients. She calls for stricter regulations around the marketing and administration of cosmetic injectables to minors and young adults, suggesting that a mandatory cooling-off period and psychological evaluation should be standard practice. She believes that practitioners have a duty of care to protect vulnerable individuals from potential harm, and this includes resisting the commercial pressures to provide treatments that may not be in the patient's best interest. The findings underscore the urgent need for a societal shift away from the relentless pursuit of an artificial ideal of perfection towards embracing natural beauty and promoting healthy self-esteem among young people in the UK and globally. This involves educating both practitioners and the public about the true purpose and potential downsides of procedures like Botox, ensuring that informed decisions are made, and that the emotional and psychological well-being of young people remains paramount. The long-term effects of widespread Botox use in this age group on collective emotional literacy and non-verbal communication are yet unknown, adding another layer of concern for experts like Helen Collier.

The association advocates for mental health and a healthy body image, advising against treatments that could have lasting negative effects on a young person's self-image and emotional development.

Collier's study, also published in the Journal of Aesthetic Nursing, implores clinicians to place the mental well-being and developmental requirements of younger patients first. She calls for more stringent rules concerning the marketing and administration of cosmetic injectables to minors and young adults, proposing that compulsory waiting periods and psychological evaluations be made routine. She suggests that medical professionals bear a duty to safeguard susceptible individuals from potential damage, which includes declining to yield to commercial incentives to provide treatments that may not serve the patient's best interests. The research underscores an pressing societal imperative to transcend the continuous quest for an artificially perfect appearance, instead promoting genuine beauty and strong self-esteem among young people, domestically and worldwide. This necessitates informing both healthcare providers and the public about the full extent and potential drawbacks of treatments like Botox, to guarantee thoughtful decisions and to ensure the emotional and psychological safety of youth is paramount. The broader, long-term consequences of Botox application in this age group on shared emotional comprehension and non-verbal communication are still unquantified, heightening the concerns of experts like Helen Collier.

Type_2:
The weapon was one of a pair of daggers discovered by British archaeologist Howard Carter in 1925 within the burial wrappings of the teenaged king . The origin of its unrusted iron blade has baffled scientists because such metalwork was rare in ancient Egypt . Tutankhamun was mummified more than 3,300 years ago . Italian and Egyptian researchers used " a non - invasive X - ray technique " to confirm that the iron blade was indeed of extraterrestrial origin, likely from a meteorite. The study, published in the journal Meteoritics and Planetary Science, analyzed the blade's elemental composition, revealing high levels of nickel and cobalt, elements typically found in iron meteorites but rare in terrestrial iron. This groundbreaking finding provided a definitive answer to a long-standing archaeological mystery that had puzzled experts since Howard Carters initial discovery of the dagger in Tutankhamun's tomb.

The sophisticated X-ray fluorescence analysis, conducted by researchers from the Polytechnic University of Milan and the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, eliminated any doubt about the blade's celestial source. The presence of nickel, in particular, was a key indicator, as iron extracted from ores on Earth rarely contains such high concentrations. This suggests that ancient Egyptian metallurgists, despite their advanced skills in working with gold and copper, utilized this unique, readily available raw material from the sky. The fact that the dagger has remained largely uncorroded for over three millennia further supports its meteoric origin, as meteoric iron is often more resistant to rust due to its unique crystalline structure and composition.

This discovery sheds new light on the technological capabilities and available resources in ancient Egypt during the New Kingdom period. It implies that the Egyptians were not only aware of falling 'sky-iron' but also possessed the skills to forge it into intricate objects of immense value, fit for a pharaoh like Tutankhamun. The cultural significance of such a material, literally descended from the heavens, would have been profound, adding to the mystique and power attributed to the young king. The other dagger found alongside it was made of gold, contrasting sharply with the 'celestial' iron one, highlighting the distinct and perhaps revered nature of the iron blade. This research emphasizes the interdisciplinary approach needed to unravel the secrets of ancient civilizations, combining archaeology, art history, and modern scientific analysis to provide unprecedented insights into the past of Tut and his people.

However, a joint team of Italian and Egyptian researchers, employing a non-destructive X-ray technique, recently confirmed its extraterrestrial origin, almost certainly from a meteorite. Their study, detailed in *Meteoritics and Planetary Science*, revealed the blades elemental composition, which included high concentrations of nickel and cobaltelements characteristic of iron meteorites but seldom found in terrestrial iron. This pivotal discovery conclusively resolved an enduring archaeological enigma that had puzzled scholars since Carters initial finding in Tutankhamun's tomb.

The advanced X-ray fluorescence analysis, conducted by experts from the Polytechnic University of Milan and the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, unequivocally established the blade's cosmic provenance. This suggests that ancient Egyptian metallurgists, despite their impressive skills in working with gold and copper, recognized and utilized this unique, naturally available material that descended from the sky. Furthermore, the dagger's exceptional resistance to corrosion over more than three millennia lends additional credence to its meteoric origin, as this type of iron is often more durable due to its distinct crystalline structure and composition.

This finding provides significant insights into the technological capabilities and material resources accessible during Egypt's New Kingdom period. It implies that the Egyptians were not only aware of falling "sky-iron" but also possessed the sophisticated knowledge to forge it into intricate, highly valued objects befitting a pharaoh like Tutankhamun. The cultural and symbolic significance of a material literally from the heavens would have been profound, undoubtedly enhancing the mystique and authority associated with the youthful monarch. Notably, the other dagger discovered alongside it was crafted from gold, sharply contrasting with the 'celestial' iron one and underscoring the iron blade's distinct and perhaps revered status. This research powerfully demonstrates the value of an interdisciplinary approachintegrating archaeology, art history, and modern scientific analysisto unlock unprecedented understandings of Tutankhamun's past and his civilization.

However, a recent collaborative effort by Italian and Egyptian researchers utilized a non-invasive X-ray technique to confirm its extraterrestrial origin, most likely from a meteorite. The findings, detailed in *Meteoritics and Planetary Science*, revealed the blade's unique chemical composition, particularly its high concentrations of nickel and cobaltelements characteristic of iron meteorites but seldom found in terrestrial iron. This significant discovery finally provided a definitive answer to a profound archaeological mystery that had intrigued academics since its initial finding in Tutankhamun's tomb.

Specialists from Milan's Polytechnic University and the Egyptian Museum in Cairo further substantiated the blade's celestial source through advanced X-ray fluorescence analysis. This finding suggests that ancient Egyptian metalworkers, despite their renowned skill with gold and copper, were able to identify and skillfully work with this distinct "sky-metal" that had fallen from space. Furthermore, the dagger's remarkable resilience to degradation over three millennia lends additional credence to its extraterrestrial origins, as meteoric iron often exhibits superior durability owing to its distinct crystalline structure and elemental makeup.

Type_2:
For the first time , MPs have agreed in a vote that we will begin the process of leaving the EU by the end of March . The government chief whip was seen with a massive grin after tonight 's vote . Remember ministers ' climbdown came with a clever kicker , persuading Labour to sign up to their timetable for triggering Article 50 without committing to very much in return The 'clever kicker' was the governments commitment to publish a Brexit white paper and allow a parliamentary debate on the negotiating strategy before Article 50 is invoked. This strategic concession offered vital political cover for Labour MPs, particularly those representing pro-remain constituencies. It enabled them to vote for the timetable, framing their support as a push for parliamentary scrutiny rather than capitulation to Theresa Mays agenda. This allowed them to appease concerned constituents and avoid accusations of obstructing the democratic will.

For Theresa May, this parliamentary triumph is paramount. It solidifies her authority over the Brexit process, demonstrating her ability to command a Commons majority for her timeline. The chief whips satisfaction signalled successful navigation of perilous political currents, momentarily silencing critics. This outcome strengthens Mays hand for complex negotiations with the EU, reinforcing her narrative that the UK is united in its resolve to leave by the deadline. The focus now shifts decisively from the mechanism of triggering Article 50 to defining Britain's future relationship with Europe.

However, deep divisions persist. While Labours leadership found a pragmatic way through, many within the party and the broader remain camp remain uneasy. The white paper offers limited real parliamentary power over final Brexit terms. Pro-remain voices will undoubtedly intensify as the immense complexities of disentangling from the EU become clearer, especially regarding single market and customs union access. The coming months will severely test the governments resolve and party cohesion as Brexits true impact unfolds. This vote merely concludes the first chapter, ushering in the far more challenging phase of withdrawal and negotiation.
